div.p: DRAMATIC DIALOGUES, FOR THE USE OF YOUNG PERSONS.
BY THE AUTHOR OF THE BLIND CHILD, &c.
div.q: "True Critics inquire, Does the Work relate to the Intereſts of Mankind?—Is its Object uſeful, and its End moral?—Will it inform the Underſtanding, and amend the Heart?" ESSAY ON SOLITUDE, BY M. ZIMMERMAN.

div.head: NEW PUBLICATIONS FOR YOUNG PEOPLE, For Sale by W. SPOTSWOOD.

list.item: 1. The BLIND CHILD, or Anecdotes of the Wyndham Family.
2. THE HISTORY OF SANDFORD AND MERTON, abridged from the original Work.
3. The TWO COUSINS, a MORAL STORY. By the Author of the BLIND CHILD.
4. The HISTORY OF THE DAVENPORT FAMILY, a moral tale.
5. TALES FOR YOUTH in thirty poems. To which are annexed Hiſtorical Remarks and Moral Applications, in proſe.

div.head: PREFACE.
div.p:
TO publiſh a Work with the Title borne by this, may, perhaps, by ſome, be thought preſumption, when it is recollected that Madame de Genlis has already occupied the Dramatic line, in a manner to be imitated by few, and, probably, to be equalled by none.—But a compariſon of this work with the Theatre of Education, of that great Author, would be unfair as to execution, and unjuſt as to deſign.—The Writer of this Work does not, like Madame de Genlis, intend her Dramatic Dialogues to be performed; well aware that the length of the Scenes, in ſome places, and the ſimplicity of the Plot in all, would render them • lat and heavy in repreſentation. The motives by which ſhe was induced to throw her Stories
into Dialogue, were a belief that young people are eaſily captivated and intereſted by this manner of writing, and the convenience of avoiding the "ſaid 〈◊〉 ," and "replied ſhe," which becomes ſo fatiguing in a narration of any length, and which ſhe was ſo often obliged to break in her laſt work.
This ſhort explanation the Authoreſs thought due to herſelf, leſt ſhe ſhould be ſuſpected of endeavouring to imitate one of the firſt Authors the Age has produces.

If theſe ſimple Dialogues ſhould be conſidered as an additional barrier againſt the encroachments of Error, and an additional ſupport to the efforts of Virtue, the Writer will be moſt happy; and ſhe truſts them, tho' not without fear, yet not without hope, to the candour of a generous Public, who at leaſt will give her credit for purity of 〈◊〉

q.l: Our Paſſions gone, and Reaſon in her Throne,
We wonder at the Miſchief we have done.

div.head: THE Misfortunes of Anger.
div.stage: Mary enters, lifts up a tambour frame which appears to have been thrown down, picks up the ſpangles, ſilks, &c.—She ſpeaks.
div.p:
SO Miſs Juliet has been here, I ſee!—What put her into a • age with her tambour, I 〈◊〉 —Oh! I ſee, this roſe-bud d •••
〈◊〉 look well, ſo down it we •• , 〈◊〉 warrant it, and here 〈◊◊〉 ſpangles and twiſt thrown 〈…〉 . For my pa • t, 〈…〉
frame was not all broke to ſmaſh, it would have been like her.—Ah! here comes Miſs Paulina! There's a young lady, marry, I wiſh our's was like her, but no hope of that!

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: Mary have you ſeen my couſin?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: No, Miſs, not ſince breakfaſt.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: I left her here at her tambour frame—She ſaid ſhe would work while I read to her.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Aye, Miſs, but ſomething has gone wrong ſince that.—Here I found the frame, and there lay the ſi • ks—Truly, I'm glad I was not here, they'd have been thrown at my head.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: Perhaps ſhe is gone to her own room, I'll ſeek her; if ſhe comes here in the mean time, Mary tell her I am up ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Yes, Miſs, to be ſure I will.—(Paulina goes out.)—Ah! by my truth, there's ſome pleaſure in doing any thing for you, one does not get pinched and called names!—So here's the Governeſs, yawning as uſual, but juſt up.

div.stage: (She ſpeaks in a ſlow, dull manner, and yawns often.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: Well, Mary!—Where's Miſs Juliet?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I don't know, Ma'am, not I, ſhe is in one of her paſſions to-day; every thing goes wrong with her; ſhe was ready to fight with the looking-glaſs, while I dreſſed her this morning, and I don't know how many pinches I got for not being quick enough to pleaſe her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p:
She's a ſtrange
girl, I can't help laughing at her ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: 'Tis no laughing matter, ma'am, I can tell you that, and it only makes her worſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: She fatigues me ſo! I really cannot ſtay with her long at a time.

sp.speaker: Mary,
sp.p: No, truly, you take care not to have too much trouble!
sp.stage: Mrs. Selwyn draws a chair indolently, and takes out her work.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: Well, Mary, go and tell her to come to me, I want her to read.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Lord, ma'am I'm quite afraid to go, ſhe won't mind me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn,
sp.p: And ſhe'll fatigue me ſadly too, well, never mind, ſhe'll come bye-and-bye.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: What's the matter with you, Fanny, what are you crying for?

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Miſs Juliet!—Miſs Juliet!—Oh dear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: Child, don't make ſo much noiſe, what has Miſs Juliet done to you?

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Why, ma'am, an pleaſe you, ſhe met me in the garden, about half an hour agone, I was a coming up, ma'am, to beg a little milk for my little ſiſter, for mother is very bad, and ſo ſhe ſaid as how—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: Don't talk ſo faſt, let's hear what Miſs Juliet did.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am, and ſo ma'am, if you pleaſe, I met Miſs Juliet; and ſo ſhe aſked me what I wanted, and ſo I told, and ſo ſhe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: Grant me patience! How many more ſo's?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Don't make ſuch a long ſtory, Fanny, tell us, at once, what made you cry.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Yes, I'm a going, ſo miſs aſked me to play wi' ſhe, for ſhe ſaid his honour was gone out and Madam Selwyn wa'nt up, and Maſter Charles was gone to ſchool, and Miſs Paulina was up ſtairs, and ſhe did not know what to do wi' herſelf.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: So, there's all the family diſpoſed of.—Well, child, what then?

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Then we vent up ſtairs ma'am, and miſs ſhewed me her doll, and we played, but at laſt,—Oh dear, oh dear!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: I never heard ſuch a girl in my life.—What happened then?

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Why, miſs beat me, yes, ſhe did, ever ſo hard, and ſcratch'd me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: What all at once, without any cauſe?

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am, 'cauſe I let the doll fall.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn,
sp.p: What nonſenſe!—Go away, child, take your milk, and bid • he cook give you ſome broth.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am, thank you ma'am. (Aſide.)—But I wo'nt come here any more to be beat about ſo. (Mary and Fanny go out.)

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Where's Fanny Wood?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: Gone home, miſs, do you think any body will ſtay where you are, to be beat and ſcratched?

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p:
I don't care. What
buſineſs had ſhe to throw down my doll?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: Do you think ſhe did it on purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: I don't know.—Let her take more care then.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: Has ſhe ſpoil'd it?

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: Well then, what was there to be in ſuch a rage about?—Come and read.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Not till I have dreſſed my doll.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: Well,—make haſte then—(A pauſe, Mrs. Selwyn works but ſlowly and idly, Juliet dreſſes her doll, at laſt, ſhe ſtamps her fo • t, and ſays:—
You tireſome creature, won't you be dreſs'd?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: My ſtars, Miſs Juliet, how you make one ſtart.—What is the matter now?

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Why, my naſty doll is ſuch a torment.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: Very pretty, to quarrel with a bit of painted wood!—Oh! you ſilly child!—Come, leave your doll, and let me hear you read.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: I tell you I won't.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: Oh! you are a ſweet little girl, ſo mild and ſo obliging; how every body loves you.

sp.speaker: Juliet,
sp.p: Let me alone then!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: Pretty creature!—What a ſweet face!—Look how your doll ſtares at you!

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.stage: (Riſing in a paſſion, and throwing her doll acroſs the room.)
sp.p: I wiſh the doll was a thouſand miles off, a little provoking creature!—(Mrs. Selwyn laughs.)—I won't be laugh'd at that I won't.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p:
How will you
help it?—Leave off crying directly, or I will ſhut you up for two hours.—(Another pauſe, Juliet ſtill cries, but by degrees becomes quiet, after ſome time ſhe calls.)—Mary!—Mary

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: What now, miſs?

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: I want Mary.—(calls)—Mary, I ſay!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Mercy, miſs I came as ſoon as ever I heard you.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: You are always ſo ſlow.—Take down my goldfinch, and fetch me ſome ſeed and water.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Yes miſs. (She reaches the bird down, then goes out, and returns with ſome water and ſeed.)

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Come my pretty, let your miſtreſs feed you, I love you very much—(She feeds it.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: Yes, you love it vaſtly juſt now, but ſometimes you are ready to wring its neck, when it does not eat to please you.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: One would think Mrs. Selwyn liked to ſee her in a paſſion, ſhe delights ſo in teazing her!

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Oh, you little torment you won't eat out of my hand!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: There, I told you ſo, now, miſs, you had better beat the bird, or throw it acroſs the room, as you did your doll.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: So I will, if I please.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: Do, I would adviſe you!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Dear ma'am, how can you?

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p:
Come, eat then.—You won't!—You naſty, little obſtinate, ungrateful creature,—I'll
teach you to teaze me, I will.—(She ſnatches the bird out of the cage in a paſſion, gives it a ſqueeze, then looks at it, and burſts into tears.)—Oh! Heaven, I have killed my bird!—

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Oh, dear, miſs, I hope not.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Look at it, Mary, pray try if you can fetch it to life!—Oh my poor bird.—Is it dead, Mary?—

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Yes, miſs, you have killed it.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: I!—I have killed it!—I that loved it ſo!—Oh! how unhappy I am!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Don't cry ſo, miſs, you was not ſo much to blame now.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: Dear Juliet, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Oh! couſin, why did you leave me?—I am never ſo naug •• y when you are with me.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: My dear, I have been ſeeking you, at laſt I heard you was playing with Fanny Wood, ſo then I ſat down to write to mama—But what has happened?—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: Oh Miſs Juliet has been in one of her uſual furies.—I muſt dreſs.—I am tired out with her.—Mary will tell you, Miſs Paulina.

sp.speaker: Mary,
sp.p: And 'tis as much your fault as her's this time, I muſt ſay, teaze, teaze, for ever.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: Mary, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Shall I tell, miſs?

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Oh! my couſin will hate me.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p:
I hate you, my dear, no •
〈◊〉 ſhall pity you.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Why, miſs, my young lady was feeding her bird, and •• rt it ſomehow, and 'tis dead.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: No, Paulina, that is not all; I was angry with my poor bird, I gave it a ſudden ſqueeze, and killed it.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: My dear couſin, you almoſt redeem your faults by this openneſs of heart.—How I pity you, how much you muſt feel on this occaſion!

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: But you, who are ſo good, how much you muſt deteſt me!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: To tell you the truth, Miſs Paulina, my young lady was not ſo much to blame as ſhe is ſometimes. Mrs. Selwyn did teaze her ſadly, that ſhe did, to be ſure.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p:
But that was not my
bird's fault!—Ah, my poor bird, he will never eat out of my hand again!—How could I be ſo cruel as to hurt a little creature who loved me ſo dearly.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: Leave us, Mary.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: Do not diſtreſs yourſelf ſo much, my dear Juliet.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Do I not deſerve to be diſtreſſed?

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: You have certainly been wrong.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Ah! You do not know half how naughty I have been: I pinched Mary, I beat Fanny Wood!—What is it makes me ſo wicked, Paulina? I always know when I am ſo, and I am unhappy, then I fret, and do wrong again.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p:
I can eaſily conceive
all that, you are greatly to be pitied.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: But you are the only perſon (except my father) who ever ſpeaks to me as if I had common ſenſe!—Mary ſhrugs up her ſhoulders and leaves me as ſoon as ſhe can.—Mrs. Selwyn laughs at me and treats me like a baby. It was but juſt now ſhe bade me "look how my doll ſtared at me!" And that put me into ſuch a paſſion, that I threw my doll acroſs the room.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p:
Certainly Mrs. Selwyn does not treat you properly, but that does not juſtify you. You are now, my dear, more than twelve years old; at that age, though children, we are no longer babies, but you do not ſeek to improve yourſelf. You read, indeed, becauſe you love reading, but not
with a ſteady view to your own improvement, and almoſt all the remainder of your time is ſpent in dreſſing your doll and playing with Fanny Wood, who is too ignorant to be a proper companion for you; thus you tempt others to treat you like a baby.—I do not offend you?

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: No, no,—I like to hear you becauſe you ſpeak to me gently, and I feel what you ſay. Pray, dear Paulina, tell me what I muſt do to be like you.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p:
My dear Juliet, I wiſh you a better example;—if you were with us, mama would ſoon teach you to be all your friends could wiſh.—But Juliet, with the underſtanding nature has given you, you may do much for yourſelf. In the words of a very great author I will tell you that
—"There is no ſoul
More ableto direct you than yourſelf,
If with the ſap of Reaſon you would quench
Or but allay the Fire of Paſſion!"—

div.p: Read more, and reflect.—Whenever you find yourſelf getting angry leave the cauſe of your diſpleaſure, take a book which amuſes you, and read till you find yourſelf calm and eaſy. Struggle with your violent paſſions, and think to what dreadful conſequences they will lead if you indulge them.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Conſequences!

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p:
Yes, my dear couſin, I know not to what an exceſs they may tranſport you in time, if they are not now oppoſed.—My mother told me, the other day, ſhe had juſt read the hiſtory of a man, who, when a boy, ſqueezed his ſquirrel to death
as you did your bird, and when he grew up, after various crimes, being angry with his wife, his child, who was in her arms, happened to cry while he was ſpeaking and, in a fit of paſſion, he laid his hand on it, and ſtrangled it in a moment!

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Oh! Heaven, how ſhocking; do you think it poſſible, Paulina, do you think it poſſible I ſhould ever do ſo?

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p:
It is impoſſible to ſay to what extravagance paſſion may lead!—But yeſterday you would have deteſted the idea of injuring your bird—and are we not told i • the Bible, that when the Prophet foretold to HazaelSee 8th Chapter of the 2d Book of Kings. the miſeries he would bring on his country, and the cruelties of which he would be
guilty, he exclaimed, "Is thy ſervant a dog that he ſhould do this great thing?"—And yet when he gave way to his paſſions, he exactly verified the Prophet's words.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Oh, Paulina! you terify me extremely—I will indeed try to be good—I will not beat Fanny, nor pinch Charles any more.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: I wiſh you may not—It is time for us to dreſs, your father will be at home preſently, and I hear Charles is juſt come from ſchool.

div.head: THE Misfortunes of Anger.
PART II.
div.stage: Juliet enters from the garden, ſhe draws a chair, ſits down, and leans her head on her hand.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p:
I HAVE a ſad head-ach, it always comes when I cry ſo much.—How true is what Paulina ſaid juſt now, that I make myſelf wretched by indulging my paſſions!—Why did nobody ever tell me ſo before?—She takes a picture from her boſom and kiſſes it.—Oh, my dear mother!—You died too early to form by your example, the
daughter you loved ſo tenderly!—Wretched girl!—Why do I ever, for a moment, forget the character which my father drew of my mother when he gave me this picture.—"Be like your mother, my Juliet; ſhe was mild and gentle to all, ſhe was beloved by every one who knew her! her dying wiſh was, that you might be virtuous!—My child, be worthy of your mother!—Yes, thoſe were exactly his words. Ah! how little do I fulfil her wiſhes!—I, who ill-treat the ſervant to whoſe care ſhe intruſted my infancy—Who abuſe a poor child whoſe ſituation ſhould make me pity her!—I whom every body hates!—Torn by contrary feelings!—Capable of knowing when I do wrong, yet yielding to the next temptation.—In ſpite of my faults, am I not to be pitied?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Miſs, my maſter bade me tell you he is going to Mr. Richley's, and ſhall be back in leſs than an hour.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: What is the matter miſs, you are crying?

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: I have reaſon to cry.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I am ſure, miſs, I don't know any young lady who might be happier.—You have the beſt of fathers.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Ah! that is true.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: And here you have a fine houſe, where you are, as one may ſay, miſtreſs, and a carriage, and every earthly thing you can wiſh.—Only think of the poor children down in the village: the little Wood's whoſe mother is ſo ſick, and who are half ſtarved!

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Alas, yes!—And I have ill-treated poor Fanny!—My dear Mary, do go down to the village and give her this ſhilling; I will beg papa, preſently, to ſend our apothecary to her mother.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Oh, miſs, what a pity you are not always good, how every body would love you.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: I hope they will in future.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: Juliet, what are you going to do?

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: I am going to read to Mrs. Selwyn, in her own room, and afterwards Charles and I are going to play.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: Very well, then I will finiſh my letter to mama.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p:
Do ſo.—I ſhall not ſtay long with Mrs. Selwyn.—Let
me know, Mary, when my father comes in.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Yes, miſs.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Miſs Juliet ſeems very unhappy to-day.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: Yes, ſhe has naturally a ſtrong ſenſe of what is right; ſhe feels that ſhe is wrong, and of courſe is unhappy.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I cannot help loving her, though ſhe is ſometimes ſo much out of the way. She was a ſweet child before ſhe grew ſo paſſionate, and ſhe has a great deal of good about her ſtill. How my poor lady would have grieved had ſhe lived to ſee her • o head-ſtrong.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p:
Had it pleaſed Heaven to ſpare Mrs. Beecher, Juliet would probably have been a very
different character; ſhe has an admirable underſtanding, but ſhe is ill educated.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: That's true, indeed, miſs. I take the liberty of ſpeaking to you becauſe you know how I love all his family, and that I have lived in it long enough to know ſomething about it.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: Yes, Mary, you may ſpeak to me without fear; I know your attachment to your late lady and all that belonged to her.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Ah, miſs, I wiſh my young lady lived with you, you are ſo mild and ſo ſenſible, and my lady your mother is ſo fine a character—

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: I have reaſon to glory in my mother—May I be one day like her.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p:
You will, miſs, • ay, you are already; truly I hear of you
from all parts.—But I know yo • don't wiſh to be praiſed.—What I was going to ſay, is this:—Nobody hears us?—No.—Indeed, Miſs Paulina, Mrs. Selwyn is not fit to have the care of my young lady.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: It is true indeed.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: She ſets her no example but lazineſs, and ſhe teazes her out of her wits;—if you had but heard her this morning—

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p:
I ſee it with pain. She has no command over my couſin, becauſe ſhe puts herſelf on a level with her by mean teazing and raillery;—a paſſionate temper was never mended by irritation.—By the way, I don't much like this ſcheme of playing with Charles; Juliet and he always quarrel, and I am afraid he will overthrow all her good reſolutions. I mean to ſpeak to my uncle, to-night, about Mrs.
Selwyn, not to blame or cenſure her, but merely to ſay I think ſhe does not exactly follow the right method of managing my couſin's temper.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Truly I think not.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: I intend to aſk my uncle to • et Juliet return with me, I know mama wiſhes it.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I wiſh • e may, miſs, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: Well, I will go and write my letter.
sp.stage: (She is going, when Juliet ruſhes in apparently much terrified.)

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Oh Paulina!—Mary!—Help, help!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Oh dear, miſs what, is the matter?

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: My brother!—help—help him!—go to him.
sp.stage: (Mary runs out, Juliet ſinks down with her head againſt a chair, Paulina goes to her.)

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: Couſin!—My dear Juliet, what is the matter?—Oh, Heaven! ſhe is fainting!—What ſhall I do, ſhall I run to Charles?—No, I cannot leave this dear girl.—Juliet, revive, ſmell to my ſalts.—(Juliet recovering, riſes on her knees, and clings round Paulina.)

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Oh, Paulina!—Send for ſome help.—Run to my father.—My father!—Good Heaven! he will hate me for ever.—I ſhall be baniſhed his ſight; plead for me Paulina!—Wretched girl!—What will become of me!

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: For pity's ſake tell me what you have done?

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p:
What have I done?—I know not!—Perhaps I have ki ••
ed my brother!

sp.speaker: Paulina
sp.p: Unhappy girl!

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Oh! well may you ſhudder, well may you look at me with horror!—You who warned me; how dare I claſp my arms round you.—Thoſe hands, which, (how can I live to tell it) perhaps have murdered my brother.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: With what terror do I hear her, (She leans over her.) Wretched victim of ungovern'd paſſion!—Revive, fear not my reproaches!—Ah, thou art already too miſerable!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Ah, miſs, what ſhall we do?—I have ſent for a ſurgeon.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: How is he hurt?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Alas! I know not how much, the knife has ſtruck him near the eye.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: The knife!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p:
Yes, they were at play and quarrelled, Miſs Juliet had a
knife in her hand, which ſhe threw at him.

sp.speaker: Paulina
sp.p: How dreadful!—let us run to him!—Yet, Juliet! But why ſhould I ſeek to revive her!—Unhappy creature, ſhe wakes but to woe—Perhaps he may be blinded!—I ſtiffen with horror!—Ah I hear the ſurgeon; follow me, Mary!

div.p:
Paulina, where am I!—You will not ſpeak!—What have I done!—Ah I remember—too, too well I remember!—(She raiſes herſelf)—They are gone!—They leave me!—to die alone!—Alas I deſerve it!—Am I worthy that one creature ſhould pity me!—Yet the torments I endure!—Can they atone for my crimes?—Never, never!—Dreadful idea!—muſt I ſuffer thro' life the anguiſh I
feel at this moment?—Thro' life—what terrible fears crowd upon me!—(She kneels,) Oh God of mercy! hear me, pity me!—Ah He is a God of juſtice!—Can he forgive me who have murdered my Brother?—What a wretch am I!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Miſs Juliet, are you better?

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Yes, Mary.—Have you ſeen—

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Your brother?—yes, Miſs.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Ah, you weep!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Truly yes, I am frightened to death.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: I am the unhappy cauſe.—I dread to hear—I dare not aſk.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: The ſurgeon is with him; I could not ſtay any longer to ſee him ſuffer ſo.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Suffer!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Yes, the ſurgeon is obliged to hurt him, to find if the wound is—I cannot ſpeak it.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Mortal you would ſay? How is it that I have courage to pronounce that horrible word?—Ah, I gather courage from the exceſs of my deſpair.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Oh my poor maſter, what will he ſay!

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Do not diſtract me!—Pity for a moment the pangs I ſuffer!—Leave me, Mary, leave me, I implore you!—Go, learn it there is any hope!

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p:
I have loſt everything!—My father will drive me from him for ever—I ſhall quit every thing I love!—My friends, my relations will bluſh when my name is mentioned—Never mo ••
ſhall I reviſit theſe ſcenes, ſo dear to my infancy!—Let me not recall the years I have paſt—years of innocence and happineſs!—Go where I will, I ſhall be pointed at and hated.—Even the picture of my mother, which uſed in all my diſtreſſes to conſole me, I can never ſee again.—I ſhould fancy it reproached me.—And all this miſery I have incurred by one moment of paſſion!—Oh God, if thou ſhould'ſt this once deign to ſave me, never, never, will I be guilty again!

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: Juliet!—my dear couſin!—be comforted.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Ah! what then!—What!—may I, dare I hope!

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: Yes—the ſurgeon ſays he is in no danger.

sp.speaker: Juliet
sp.p: Oh my beſt Paulina!

sp.speaker: Paulina,
sp.p: I ran to you the inſtant I heard it.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: I have not deſerved your goodneſs.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: Ah Juliet!—if the knife had gone ever ſo little on one ſide, Charles would have been killed, or on the other, and he would have been blinded for ever.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Oh merciful Almighty God!—from what miſery has thy providence preſerved me!—even now I cannot behold myſelf without horror.—Have I deſerved the mercy I have met with?—No!—tho' innocent in intention, my action was guilty.—I could not wiſh to hurt my brother, yet took the means to do ſo!—Deteſted paſſion!—Oh Paulina, I am cured for ever!

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p:
I dare hope ſo!—
The leſſons of this day have been ſtriking.—They ſhew how one ſtep in evil leads to another.—Aweful and horrid might have been the event, but as it has proved, we will hope this inſtruction has been directed by Providence, to warn you of your danger!

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: It has done it completely.—But Paulina, where is my father?

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: I hear him now in the hall.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Oh Paulina, I dare not ſee him.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: I will go to him, and I hope, return with your pardon.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: My beſt friend—let actions ſpeak my gratitude, deign but to counſel and direct me, henceforth I will be guided by you alone.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Well, Miſs Juliet, make yourſelf eaſy, all goes well.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Thank God!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: You have had good fortune, Miſs, I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Good fortune, Ma'am! I dare to conſider it as the act of Divine Providence, if not to ſave me, yet to preſerve my father from miſery.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: You improve, Miſs, your language is really fine.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Misfortunes correct the heart, and ſtrong feelings excite ſtrong expreſſion.—I hope I ſhall improve.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p:
You aſtoniſh me—you who but this morning were dreſſing your doll, to be making wiſ •
remarks, is indeed ſurpriſing.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: I am not a fool, tho' I have acted like one.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p:
No, no, they an't very
wiſe that take you for a fool. I have often heard you talk to my maſter as ſenſible as any-body is the world.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: Miſs Juliet never indulged me with any of her ſenſible converſation.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Truly no, becauſe y •• treated her like a baby.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: You take great liberties.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Ma'am, but I have often told you you did not know my young lady ſo well as I did.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Selwyn.
sp.p: The more ſenſe ſhe has, the more ſhame for her to behave as ſhe has done.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p:
Too true indeed!—my conſcience tells me I have not the excuſe of fo • ly.—But I have ſuffered paſſion to over-run and darken all my good qualities. This one
hour has driven it from my heart. I am no longer a fooliſh child.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: Come, my deareſt Juliet—Charles is with your father, he knows all, he forgives you, he calls for you.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: I owe every-thing to you!

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: I have more good news for you—one word.
sp.stage: (Mrs. Selwyn and Mary retire to the back of the Scene.) You go home with me—you are to ſtay with us as long as you pleaſe!

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Delightful!—

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: Your father diſmiſſes Mrs. Selwyn.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Ah I am ſorry! She is poor, and ſhe has taught me many things.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p:
My good couſin, how
I love that gratitude!—your father will allow her a penſion, we have ſettled all that ſince I left you.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: Oh my beſt couſin!—how much do I owe you.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: I am overpaid if you are happy.

sp.speaker: Juliet.
sp.p: To be ſo I muſt be good.—That will be the work of your hands!—How will you be loved by your friends, by your mother, by Heaven itſelf!—yes that will repay you.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: Let us go, my uncle expects us.

figure.head: Sensibil • ity. Cecilia supporting M •• Melville.

q.l: —Exclamations, tender tones, fond tears,
And all the graceful drap'ry Pity wears,
Theſe are not Pity's ſelf, they but expreſs
Her inward ſuff'rings, by her pictured dreſs;
And theſe fair marks, reluctant I relate,
Theſe lovely ſymbols may be counterfeit.

div.head: SENSIBILITY.
div.stage: SCENE, a Dreſſing-room, at Mrs. Melville's. A Table ſtanding with Work, and Books.)
Enter Mrs. Rivers, Cecilia, and Martha.

sp.speaker: Martha.
sp.p: PRAY, ma'am, walk in, I will let my miſtreſs know you are here, ſhe is walking in the garden with Miſs Melville.—Won't you pleaſe to ſit?

sp.speaker: Mrs Rivers.
sp.p: Thank you Martha, don't hurry your miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Cecilia
sp.p: This is a pretty room, mama.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p: Very much ſo, I ſee it again with great pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: It is ſome time, I think, ſince you were here.

sp.speaker: Mrs, Rivers.
sp.p: Yes, near two years. Mrs. Melville has been gone ſo long on buſineſs of her late huſband's to an eſtate he had in Jamaica.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: How glad you will be to ſee her again! What a delightful day we ſhall ſpend?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p: It will indeed give me great pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: But her daughter!—Oh, mama, what joy to her to ſee her mother again after an abſence of two years!—I ſhould envy her, if I had not paſſed thoſe two years with the beſt of mothers.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p:
She has indeed
probably loſt much by ſo long an abſence from her who is ſo well able to inſtruct her.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: Undoubtedly!—Ah, whoſe inſtructions can teach the heart ſo ſoon as thoſe of a mother, whoſe reproofs proceed from affection, whoſe praiſes are the greateſt glory of a child!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p:
It is true,—a child muſt be obſtinate indeed, who refuſes to liſten to the inſtructions of a fond mother.—Mrs. Melville is entitled to her daughter's beſt affections, not only by the goodneſs of her heart and underſtanding, but by the ſacrifices ſhe has made for her ſake.—When Mr. Melville died, he left his large eſtate in Jamaica to his little girl: on inquiry, her mother found that the eſtate had been, and ſtill was, ill managed by the ſteward; in ſhort,
that nothing but the preſence of ſome perſon intereſted in its improvement could render it half ſo valuable as it had been ſuppoſed.—She determined, therefore, to overcome her dread of the ſea, which all her life had been extreme; to leave her friends, her ſiſter, even her child, in England, and undertake the voyage herſelf.—This ſhe has done; has reſtored the eſtate to the moſt flouriſhing condition, and is now returned to enjoy the reward of her labours.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: What a charming character!—(A ſhort pauſe.) I like this room very much, 'tis ſo pleaſant and quiet—(She riſes and walks about)—Mama, may I look at this book?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p:
If you pleaſe, a • it is lying open to every-one's inſpection, it cannot be improper, but
it is impertinent and ill-bred to look even into printed books, which are placed out of immediate view.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: "The Beauties of Sterne!"—It has Miſs Melville's name in it.—I do not know this book, Mama.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p: No, my dear, tho' it has great merit in point of writing and ſentiment, it is not exactly the book I ſhould chuſe for you at preſent. In my opinion it recommends too much the enervating mind of Senſibility, to which I ſo greatly object.—But here come Mrs. Melville and Iſabella.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: My dear friend, how much I rejoice to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p:
The pleaſure is mutual, believe me!—It is ſo long ſince we met, I began to fear we ſhould meet no more!—This is, I
believe, Miſs Melville, but ſo grown I ſhould hardly have known her!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: Not more than Miſs Rivers.—I muſt have the •• young people acquainted.
sp.stage: (Mrs. Melville introduces Cecilia and Iſabella to each other, they curtſy, and ſeem to talk apart.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p: I hope they will be ſo, nothing can give me more pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: But I forget to beg your pardon for keeping you waiting, I had ſtrolled beyond the garden into the field, and Martha could not find me.—She has ſhown you into a litter'd room.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p: No apology is neceſſary, I have long known and loved this room.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: It is my daughter's now, I gave it up to her the day after my return, and ſhe has already brought hither her books and work—ſo that ſhe has the confuſion to anſwer for—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p: It is a becoming confuſion, I like to ſee books and work about in a young perſon's apartment.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Mine would have been in better order, mama, if you had not called me away ſuddenly.—Beſides I hardly know where I am, or what I do at preſent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p: I dare ſay, my dear, you have hardly yet recovered, if I may • o expreſs myſelf, the happineſs of ſeeing your mother!

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p:
No indeed, Ma'am!—The extreme joy almoſt overcome me. It may well be called recovery, for ſuch delight is really
ſuffering!
sp.stage: (Mrs. Rivers looks at her wi • h ſome ſurpriſe.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: Mine was, and ſtill is, exquiſite!—To return once more to my friends, to my ſiſter, to my daughter, is happineſs ſo great as wholly to repay me all I have ſuffered in my abſence from them!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p: No doubt, every ſacrifice we make of pleaſure to duty will, ſooner or later, be repaid; even the conviction of having done ſo carries with it a comfort to the heart ſuperior to all the advantages to be derived from a deviation from virtue.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p:
You ſay true. It was with extreme regret that I prepared to quit England, and to leave my daughter; but the aſſurance that my departure was neceſſary to her future welfare, the
dread of endangering her health, then extremely delicate, by takeing her with me, and the conviction that I left her in proper care, conſpired to determine me, and I am now repaid.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: But, mama, I ſhould have been ſo afraid of the ſea and ſtorms!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: Go, you are a ſilly child, to form ſuch a terrible idea of dangers, which 〈◊〉 principally imaginary.—But, my dear Mrs. Rivers, will you go with me to my greenhouſe?—I have ſome curious Weſt-India plants.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p: With all my heart.—Children, will you ſtay here, or go with us?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: Oh, they ſhall remain here.—They will become better acquainted in our abſence.
sp.stage: (Mrs. Rivers and Mrs. Melville go out.)

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Let us ſit down, my dear Miſs Rivers. (They ſit.)—What pleaſure I hope to derive from your aquaintance!

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: My mother I am ſure will be happy in my forming an intimacy with you, ſhe has ſo high an opinion of Mrs. Melville!

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: It will give me infinite pleaſure.—Suffer me to ſay I already feel I ſhall love you extremely, I am already attached to you.—Dear Cecilia, may I believe the impreſſion is mutual!

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: I have no doubt, on a farther acquaintance, my gratitude for your kindneſs will ripen into real regard.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: You are very good!—(She aſſumes a melancholy air.)—Hitherto I have been very unfortunate in my friendſhips!

sp.speaker: Cecilia,
sp.p: You are very young to complain of that.

sp.speaker: Iſabella,
sp.p: Alas yes!—The misfortune of too great ſenſibility is mine.—You can have no idea what I have ſuffered—what I do at this moment ſuffer!

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: You alarm and diſtreſs me.—What at your age can have happened to make you ſo uneaſy?

sp.speaker: Iſabella,
sp.p: Alas, my dear Cecilia, amidſt all my joy for the return of my mother, I endure ſevere regret, bitter anguiſh I might call it.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: Good Heaven! on what account.

sp.speaker: Iſabella,
sp.p: Amiable girl!—I ſee you ſympathize with me.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p:
I do indeed, but ſurely
you would not have told me ſo much without intending to explain yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: No, my ſweet friend. The inflated and ſtrong language Iſabella uſes, is one ſymptom of Falſe Senſibility.—To apply violent terms on common occaſions is equally abſurd and unnatural—From your tenderneſs I expect the only conſolation of which my ſituation is capable.—How will your kind and gentle nature pity me when you hear the loſs I have ſuſtained!

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: What can it be, when your mother is ſtill with you?

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p:
At the ſeat of my aunt, where I have been during my mother's abſence, I contracted a ſtrong and ardent attachment to a young lady about your age.—I even think you reſemble her,—
you have the ſame ſoftneſs of complexion, the ſame ſweet ſmile!

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: Ah, my dear Iſabella, I will ſpare you the relation.—I gueſs too eaſily what you have ſuffered!—It is true I have never formed any friendſhip out of my own family, but I can conceive what its feelings muſt be.—And have you really loſt, for ever, a tie ſo tender?

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Not, I hope, for ever.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: How!—I have miſunderſtood you.—I believe you meant to have ſaid ſhe was dead.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Oh no!—I ſhould hardly be able to ſurvive ſo great a misfortune.—Is it not enough to be ſeparated from her?

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: You fear you ſhall, perhaps, meet her no more!

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: No.—She is to ſpend the greateſt part of the ſummer with me.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: I do not underſtand—what then do you lament?

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: What?—Surely her abſence at preſent!

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: What the abſence of a few months do you regret ſo deeply!—I profeſs you ſurpriſe me!

sp.speaker: Iſabella,
sp.p: But I have been ſo accuſtomed to ſee her every day, ſhe is ſo charming—and my misfortune is too great ſenſibility!

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p:
Can ſenſibility become a misfortune and a torment?—I have been taught to conſider it as the ſource of goodneſs and delight—True, indeed, we may be ſometimes ſeverely pained by the impoſſibility of relieving thoſe whom we pity, by the illneſs of friends, and various other circumſtances, but at the ſame time an active wiſh
to do good warms and chea • s the heart, and when we ſt •• e our anguiſh and carefully attend the ſickbed of thoſe we love, do we not feel ſuch comfort as half repays us for the ſorrow we endure in ſeeing them ſuffer!

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: But unfortunately I feel ſo much. I can do very little to relieve the pain of thoſe I love; my preſence of mind forſakes me, and I become unable to aſſiſt them.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: But pardon me for ſaying that it is a ſort of weakneſs againſt which we ought to ſtruggle, our feeling becomes uſeleſs, worſe than uſeleſs; it diſables us if it does does not prompt us to action. We might as well not feel for the unhappy, as not ſeek to relieve them.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: I ſympathiſe with them, but my ſpirits are ſo weak I can do little more.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: I proteſt I do not underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Martha.
sp.p: Oh, dear Miſs Melville, a ſad thing has happened!

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Oh Heavens! what? You alarm me beyond expreſſion!

sp.speaker: Martha.
sp.p: Don't be too much frightened, miſs, 'tis well it's no worſe, but you will be vexed?—

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: I entreat you to tell me what has happened at once.

sp.speaker: Martha.
sp.p: Why, miſs, your pretty parrot has hurt himſelf ſadly.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Ah! my poor parrot, what has he done?

sp.speaker: Martha.
sp.p:
Miſs, he was ſtanding upon his perch, when a great dog followed the baker into the kitchen, Poll was frigtened, and flew to the window, daſh'd himſelf againſt a pane of glaſs, broke
it and cut himſelf very much with the pieces.

sp.speaker: Iſabella,
sp.p: Oh? what ſhall I do, what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: My dear Iſabella, don't diſtreſs yourſelf ſo,—I dare ſay he will ſoon be well again,—let us go and ſee if we can do any thing for him.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Oh! I cannot bear to ſee him.

sp.speaker: Martha.
sp.p: Dear miſs, he will ſoon be well, but ſomebody ſhould put ſomething to the cut.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Martha, will you?

sp.speaker: Martha.
sp.p: I would with all my heart, Miſs, but I burned my hand ſo yeſterday I cannot hold him, and our ſilly cook is afraid of his biting her.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Will Thomas?

sp.speaker: Martha.
sp.p: Thomas is not at home, Miſs.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: Dear Iſabella, I will do it—'tis true I ſhall be ſorry to ſee the poor creature in pain, but I cannot bear the idea of not aſſiſting him.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: You are extremely good!

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: Poor thing! he is ſuffering all this time. Come, my dear, let us go to him.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Oh, I cannot ſee him.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: Not ſee him!

sp.speaker: Martha.
sp.p: Dear Miſs, the poor thing knows you, and he will be quiet if you are by.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Oh, but indeed it wil • make me ill.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: Pooh, pooh, a run in the garden will ſoon make you well again!

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: What ſpirits you have!

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p:
To be ſure—that is
natural at my age—what have I to be melancholy about?

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: You are very happy!

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: You have as much cauſe to be happy as I have; but come along.

sp.speaker: Martha.
sp.p: That's a charming young lady!—How ſhe runs along and how chearful ſhe looks!—What ails Miſs Iſabella, I wonder; ſhe always looks ſorrowful, and ſighs, and walks ſo ſlowly, I ſee that already.—Truly, that is unnatural at her age.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: Martha, where are the young ladies?

sp.speaker: Martha.
sp.p: Marry, Ma'am, they are gone to ſee the poor Parrot; he has hurt himſelf, and they are gone to help him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melvillie.
sp.p: Very well, they are well employed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: My dear friend, I am ſo charmed to ſee you, and ſo anxious to talk with you, that I fear I ſhall quite fatigue you with prate!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p: Not at all; aſſure yourſelf I am too much intereſted in all which concerns you, and am indeed eager to have an unreſtrained converſation with you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: I am equally eager; and as the firſt ſubject to a fond mother is her child, we will talk of ours. I am not quite ſatisfied with Iſabella.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p: How ſo?—She appears gentle and ſenſible!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p:
Yes, ſhe has many good qualities, but I ſee
with pain, that one of the moſt amiable, ſhe carries to an exceſs which makes me wiſh ſhe poſſeſſed it not: it gives her ſo much pain, and will thro' life be ſo often a ſource of diſtreſs to her, that I could almoſt wiſh to ſuppreſs it entirely.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p: Pray tell me what it is—you really alarm me!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: Senſibility.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p: I am amazed!

sp.speaker: Mrs Melville.
sp.p: I once hardly could have believed I ſhould wiſh a child of mine to want Senſibility; but I ſee in Iſabella how much it tends to increase the unavoidable diſtreſſes of human life, even to create them where they are not; ſo that I really think had I another child to educate, I ſhould labour as much as poſſible to ſuppreſs this pleaſing, but unhappy quality.

sp.speaker: Mrs Rivers.
sp.p:
I muſt repeat, you amaze me!—What! Senſibility!—The firſt and beſt gift of Heaven—would you rob your child of that?—Not only is it the ſweeteſt grace of youth, but the principal ſource of its virtues.—Can you conceive any great or good action which has ever been performed by a perſon wanting Senſibility? Did you ever hear of any really great character who wanted this endowment? Have I then a right to rob my child of that which alone can lead to exalted virtue, and to the train of delight by which it is accompanied?—How ſweetly, as well as truly, ſays a certain charming Authoreſs,
Cold and •• ert the mental powers would lie.
Without this quick'ning ſpark of Deity
To draw the rich materials from the mine,
To bid the maſs of intellect refine;
To melt the firm, to animate the cold,
And Heav'n's own impreſs ſtamp on Nature's gold;
To give immortal Mind its firmeſt tone,
Oh Senſibility!—is all thine own!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: I agree with you fully, my dear friend, as to the graces and charms of Senſibility; but allow me to differ from you a moment. Was not Cato a great character, yet had he ſenſibility, who did not ſhed a tear over the body of his ſon, juſt ſlain in battle?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p:
Undoubtedly yes.—Firſt we ought to conſider the education which was given to the Romans.—We ought to recollect that their country was the chief object of their love, and that they were taught to deſpiſe all conſiderations which interfered
with their duty to that.—Thus when Cato ſaw the dead body of his ſon, he did not weep, becauſe true Senſibility exalted his mind to the height of patriotiſm, which made him willingly yield his ſon a victim to Rome.—He wiſhed alſo to encourage the ſinking Romans, by making their lives leſs valuable in their eyes, when he, to whom they looked for example, could ſo chearfully par with that life which was dearer to him than his own.—What but Senſibility could have awakened this high ſenſe of duty, and heroic reſolution?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: But that is exactly what I complain of, Senſibility, at leaſt the ſenſibility I am uſed to ſee, enervates and weakens the mind; it deſtroys this heroic reſolution, this preference of duty to indulgence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p: "The Senſibility you are uſed to ſee," theſe words explain to me your meaning.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: You think then there are two kinds of Senſibility?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p:
Undoubtedly.—Or rather I ſhould ſay that which is commonly dignified with that charming name, is unworthy of it; and if you will allow me to ſay ſo, by what I have ſeen of Miſs Melville's, that is the Senſibility ſhe poſſeſſes, though perhaps mixed and blended with the true mind. Let us refer again to the delightful Authoreſs I have already quoted, whoſe every line contains meaning and reaſon.
Tis not to mourn becauſe a Sparrow dies,
To rave in artificial extaſi • s!
I would have Senſibility a ſpring of
Action. I would have it directed to a generous, firm line of Conduct. In ſhort, it ſhould be Principle refined and pointed. I would have young people taught to treat every creature with mercy and kindneſs, but I would not have them waſte their tenderneſs and affection on a ſet of Animals. I would have them anxious to relieve every thing in diſtreſs, but I would not have them
Boaſt quick rapture trembling in their eye,
If from the Spider's web they ſave a Fly.
Far would I be from wiſhing them to have the word Senſibility continually in their mouths, tho' I would never for an inſtant have it quit their hearts. It ought to animate, not deject them; to ſtrengthen, not enervate their minds.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p:
You are perfectly
right, my dear friend but how ſhall we teach young people to draw the line?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p:
By not ſuffering them to paſs it, without reprehenſion; by not praiſing them for feeling, by not allowing them to exaggerate their language, which leads to that hateful exaggeration of Sentiment I ſo much diſlike.—Accuſtomed to expreſs themſelves ſtrongly, to ſay they "love," they "deteſt"—they are in "anguiſh," in "extaſy," they ſtrive to make their feelings correſpond with their words: if they ſucceed, their imaginations become inflamed and deluſive; if they do not, they are perpetually affected and unnatural.—Let them aſk themſelves, whether they really feel what they expreſs, when they ſay they love or hate any-thing; let them firſt conſider
whether it is worth loving or hating, and then whether they really do love or hate it: they will then not be ſo eaſily deceived themſelves, which, I believe, generally is the caſe before they ſeek to deceive others.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: I am ſure you are right, and I ſhall earneſtly preſs this knowledge of herſelf on Iſabella.

sp.speaker: Mrs Rivers.
sp.p: I have always done ſo with Cecilia; and I wiſh young people would conſider how much more amiable, ſimple unaffected manners are, than that pompous prentence of feeling and tenderneſs of which ſome are ſo fond.

sp.speaker: Martha.
sp.p: The dinner is ready, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: Very well, we are coming.

div.head: SENSIBILITY.
PART II.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: THIS room is cooler than the dining parlour.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: It is remarkably pleaſant and quiet.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Come let us • it, I am wretchedly out of ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: I ſaw with great concern that you appeared out of ſpirits at dinner, and that your mama looked uneaſy at it.—What is the matter, are you not well?

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p:
Yes, well—that is tolerably well—but the ſight of
my poor Parrot this morning has made me quite unhappy.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: But, my dear, you ought not to ſuffer it to do ſo!

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Bleſs me! can I feel as I pleaſe?

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: In a great meaſure.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: I am glad you think ſo.—Then you are never unhappy I ſuppoſe, for I believe nobody would chuſe to be ſo!

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: Pardon me.—There are caſes in which we muſt feel unhappy, whether we ſtruggle againſt it or not: but do you not think much of our unhappineſs depends on our indulging melancholy, or ſtriving againſt it?

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Perhaps it may, but why will you not allow the preſent to be one of the caſes you mention?

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p:
I cannot think it of conſequence enough. It is true I pity the poor bird, and if I were
attached to him, as I dare ſay you are, I ſhould be extremely concerned, but ſtill as my concern would do him no good, and as I had done all I could to relieve him, I ſhould ſtrive againſt it, and make myſelf eaſy.

sp.speaker: Iſabella
sp.p: But I cannot—it makes me unhappy.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: That is what it ought not to do.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Do you make no allowance for the difference of diſpoſitions?

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: Yes,—but I alſo believe we can greatly correct and after our own.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: And you think I need this correction?

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: You are not angry with me!

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: No—but

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p:
Nay, that is unfair—
we were ſpeaking generally—you aſked my ſentiments, or I ſhould not have given them; if I have offended you I ſincerely beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: No, no, you have not offended me—yet I will own much leſs than what you have ſaid would have offended me in ſome people; but you ſpeak ſo ſenſibly, and with ſo much goodneſs, I love to hear you tho' it is to blame me.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: I did not mean to blame you: I could not think of taking that liberty.—Let us drop the ſubject.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: No, no, we will 〈◊〉 drop it.—I ſhall think you are angry, if you do not tell me all you think.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: What would you have me tell you?

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p:
Whether I really, in
your opinion, require the correction you talk of?

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: I have not a right, on ſo ſhort an acquaintance, to decide.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: You will not tell me—but I beg of you to be ſincere!

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: Well then remember you have no right to be offended.—I do think you ſuffer your feelings to govern you too much.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Well I will not diſpute the word ſuffer, ſince you ſay I might correct it, but tell me how?

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: Are you convinced the correction is neceſſary?

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Perhaps not entirely.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: Permit me to aſk you a few queſtions.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: Suppoſe your mother, or any of your friends, were ill, what would you do?

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: I ſhould be very much grieved!

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: Of courſe—but ſhould you attend to them yourſelf, or how ſhould you act?

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: I ſhould wiſh to attend them, but I fear I ſhould be too unhappy!

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: If you were yourſelf ill, how ſhould you expect your mother to act?

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Oh I know very well ſhe would attend me conſtantly!

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: Well, do you not believe ſhe would feel a great deal?

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Oh yes, I am ſure of it!

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: Should you not be very much diſtreſs'd, if, inſtead of attending you, ſhe diſturbed you by continual ſighs and tears, and rendered herſelf ſo incapable of aſſiſting 〈◊〉 be obliged to leave you to the care of ſervants?

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Certainly!

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: The inference is ſo obvious, I will leave you to draw it for your ſelf.—Only let me hint, if every-body felt as you ſay you do, and acted in conſequence, what would become of thoſe who are ſick, or in danger?

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: You are certainly right—but how am I to conquer this exceſſive feeling?

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: Simply by not indulging it—Perhaps your mind will ſometimes turn itſelf from a ſuffering object; but do not heed it.—Force it to act.—Do not ſay "I cannot"—but try.—Think you can, and you will be able.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Do you think ſo?

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p:
I am even ſure of it.—I will give you an inſtance; I am myſelf extremely afraid of Fire! and uſed to tell my mama I believed
if my bed were on fire, I ſhould be burnt for want of reſolution to move. She took a great deal of pains to reaſon me out of this belief, which ſhe foreſaw might be ſo dangerous.—Laſt ſummer, when we were at my aunt's, I was one evening in my own room, which joins the nurſery, where her little girl was ſleeping, the nurſery maid was juſt gone down ſtairs, I ſmelt fire, and running into the nurſery, ſaw that the cat had jumped on a table where the maid had placed a candle, and had beat the candle into the cradle where the baby was—the quilt was in a blaze!

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Oh mercy!—what did you do?

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p:
My firſt impulſe was to run for help, but ſtruck with the idea that the infant would be burnt 〈◊〉 ſtifled before help could arrive,
I ſaid to myſelf "Oh mama, let me now remember your leſſons!"—I flew to the cradle, ſnatched up a ſmall carpet, and threw into the cradle; it extinguiſhed the flame: I then ſeized the child, and ran with her down ſtairs.—You may ſuppoſe that my mother and aunt thought me diſtracted; but when I explained to them what had happened, I thought my aunt would never ceaſe thanking and praiſing me.—She told me I had ſaved her from deſpair and diſtraction; that her child ſhould be taught to love me as a ſecond mother.—I ſhort I cannot repeat to you half ſhe ſaid, or deſcribe the painful delight I felt in her gratitude and joy.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: But did you not ſuffer from the fright?

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p:
A little.—I felt ſick
and faint; mama gave me ſome drops, and I cried a good deal; after which I was quite well, and never can think myſelf grateful enough to Heaven, for giving me courage to reſcue the poor infant!

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Well, I admire you!—but I fear I ſhould never be able to imitate you!

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: Only give me your promiſe that you will try, and I am ſure you will be able.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Melville and Mrs. Rivers.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p: So my dear girls you have run away from us!—Indeed the dining parlour is ſo warm, that we •• re glad to quit it alſo.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: It is very warm indeed, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: I am afraid you are not well, 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: Not very well indeed.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Oh, mama, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p: Are you ſaint?—Sit down.
sp.stage: (She places a chair, and Mrs. Melville • is down.)

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Speak to me mama!—Oh, what ſhall I do!

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: My dear, you alarm your mama 〈◊〉 ſhe will be better preſently; I will fetch ſome water.

stage.hi: (She runs out. Mrs. Rivers gives her 〈◊〉 to Mrs. Melville, who becomes more and more faint. Iſabella runs about diſtractedly and crying.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p: My dear Iſabella, don't be ſo frightened! Open the window, and bathe your mother's forehead with this Hungary water.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Oh I cannot, indeed I cannot, I am ſo frighten'd!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p: Silly girl, how can you be ſuch a coward!
sp.stage: (Cecilia returns with water. Martha comes in; they ſprinkle Mrs. Melville with water. Cecilia ſupports her. Iſabella continues crying.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p: Iſabella, I am quite aſhamed of you—how can you be ſo childiſh!

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Oh, mama is dying, I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Mrs.. Rivers.
sp.p: Dying!—what nonſenſe!—ſhe is even now recovering.—My dear friend, are you better?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: Yes, I am better, I thank you.—My eyes are ſtill dim.—Who is this ſupporting me?—My dear Iſabella!—Dear child, do not be alarmed, I am better!
sp.stage: (Iſabella advances. Cecilia makes ſigns to her come forward.)

sp.speaker: Martha.
sp.p: Dear ma'am, we are all frightened, Miſs Iſabella is as bad as you almoſt!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville,
sp.p: Don't be frighted, my love; I am better indeed,—I ought to be well, when you are ſo attentive to me—Ah! what happineſs for a mother to be ſupported in the arms of her child.—I feel your tears on my face, ſpeak to me Iſabella.

sp.speaker: Iſabella,

stage.hi: (falling on her 〈◊〉 before her mother, and kiſſing her hands)

sp.p: Ah mama, I am here!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: Who then is this?—Cecilia!—It is to you then that I am obliged for aſſiſtance! (A ſhort pause, during which Iſabella appears much confuſed.)—Thank you, my dear.—I am ſubject to theſe attacks in warm weather, but I am now well.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p: My dear Mrs. Melville, had you not better go to your own room?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: I will preſently; you and Cecilia will have the goodneſs to aſſiſt me?

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Ah mama, why do you not ſay Iſabella will aſſiſt me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: We naturally look for help towards thoſe from whom we have received it.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Ah mama, it is true indeed I have not been ſo happy as to be of uſe to you, but can you believe I did not wiſh it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: We can only judge of the heart by the actions it produces.

sp.speaker: Cecilia,
sp.p: Dear ma'am, if you could have ſeen Iſabella's diſtreſs, her alarm—ſhe is incapable.—Oh can you believe your child could neglect you!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: Generous girl! how I love that amiable warmth.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Mother, my deareſt mother forgive me!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: If you are conſcious of no offence, why aſk forgiveneſs?

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Can I think myſelf innocent, when you are diſpleaſed with me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rivers.
sp.p: How amiable is that ſentiment! It muſt procure your pardon.—My dear friend, believe me, Iſabella ſuffered exceedingly; her diſtreſs alone cauſed that appearance of neglect you condemn.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: If too much feeling, or too little cauſe the ſame effect, ought they not to be equally condemned?

sp.speaker: Ms. Rivers.
sp.p:
If not equally, both ought to be.—But this is not
a time to argue.—You will increaſe your indiſpoſition by talking, and at leaſt Iſabella cannot feel your diſpleaſure too much.—Forgive her, I beg of you!

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: Deareſt madam, forgive Iſabella.—Look at her; can you ſee her diſtreſs, and not pity her?—Her conſtitution is ſlight; the alarm was too much for her.—Her extreme affection for you was the cauſe of it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: Riſe, my dear girl, I forgive the apparent ſlight.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Oh believe, believe it could not proceed from my heart!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p:
Let us ſpeak of it no more, but correct and ſuppreſs in future, I beg of you, that exceſs of feeling, which renders you incapable of doing your duty.—Come, my
dear friend, you will have the the goodneſs to go with me into my own room.—I will lie down awhile.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Mama, will you not ſuffer me to aſſiſt you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: If I do not, my dear, it is not becauſe I am ſtill angry with you; but becauſe I do not need your attendance: in leſs than an hour I dare ſay I ſhall be well enough to meet you at the tea-table.—This faintneſs has only been owing to the heat; I have felt it all day.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: And yet you have not complained.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Melville.
sp.p: No, ſince complaining could not cool the air, and conſequently could not relieve my faintneſs.—Stay here, my child, with Cecilia, and both of you recover yourſelves before I return.

stage.hi: (Mrs. Melville, Mrs. Rivers, and Martha go out.)

div.stage: (Iſabella • its down, and leans her head on her hand.)

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: My dear, will you take a little hartſhorn and water?

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: No, thank you.

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: Be eaſy, my dear girl ſince your mama is quite reconciled to you!

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Ah Cecilia, if I had but recollected your kind and wife counſels, I ſhould not have incured her diſpleaſure!

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: In future, you will, I doubt not, act otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p:
I hope ſo!—Never let me again incur a pang ſo ſevere as that I felt when my mother ſpoke of the ſweetneſs of being aſſiſted by her child, when I had
not been of the leaſt ſervice to her.—And again, when ſhe ſaid "You and Cecilia will aſſiſt me"—as if I were not there! as if, alas, but too juſtly, I were a uſeleſs, helpleſs being!

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: Let us drop theſe unpleaſant ideas, and hope that the conſequence will be a fixed reſolution on your part to encourage fortitude and activity, and to repreſs enervating and exceſſive feeling.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: It ſhall indeed; and ſtill, dear Cecilia, counſel and adviſe me. Be as ſincere as I have hitherto found you; be my monitor, my adviſer, and my advocate.—Dear girl, (embracing her) how 〈◊〉 I ever enough thank you for th • ſe generous tears you ſhed, when pleading for me to my mother!—My heart, at leaſt, has for once elected a real friend!

sp.speaker: Cecilia.
sp.p: I hope ſo, but the ſame facility with which I was exalted to that character, might expoſe you to much deceit and treachery.—You ſee I uſe the privilege you give me.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: Do ſo always, and aſſiſt me if you can, to root up my idle prejudices altogether, and to renounce, for ever, the exaggerated expreſſions and unnatural ſentiments of that which you have convinced me is falſe SENSIBILITY.

div.q: The Story of Melanthon affords a ſtriking Leſſon on the Value of Time, which was, that whenever he made an appointment, he always expected not only the Hour, but the Minute, ſhould be fixed; that the Day might not run out in the Idleneſs of Suſpence. JOHNSON.

list.head: CHARACTERS.
list.item: Mrs. Cecil, Governeſs to the Miſs Mildmays.
Ruth Saunders, A Poor Woman. Sally.

div.head: THE LITTLE TRIFLER.
div.stage: SCENE a Room with Book-caſes, Globes, a Harpſichord, &c.
Enter Mrs. Cecil, Sophia, and Eudocia.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: I FEEL ſo chearful this fine morning, that I hope I ſhall get through my employments comfortably before we go for our ride.

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: Yes, and the ſun is ſo enlivening, we ſhall enjoy our airing of all things.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: To do that, you muſt all of you perform your taſks well.—As to Miſs Mildmay, I need not remind her, ſhe is always ready.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: You are always too good to me, my dear governeſs.

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: Not better than you deſerve, Sophia, we are all ready to allow that.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: Yes, yes, the praiſe of candour and affection belongs to you equally.—But we loſe time.—Where is Miſs Laura?—Idling, I dare ſay. I never ſhall ſucceed in my endeavours to teach that child the value of thoſe minutes ſhe waſtes ſo abominably!—Nothing but a concurrence of circumſtances will make her aware of the neceſſity there is, if we would go through our duties properly, of being punctual. 'Tis paſt nine, ſhe muſt know it, and yet ſhe is not here.—Do, Miſs Eudocia, ring the bell. (Eudocia rings the bell, they draw a ſmall table, and ſit down to work.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: Sally, pray tell Miſs Laura 'tis paſt nine; I want her here.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: Don't you think Sally a very good girl ma'am?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: Yes, I do indeed. Your mama has had her in her ſervice ſix years, all that time ſhe has behaved unexceptionably. She was very young when ſhe came hither, and had before been tolerably educated; therefore I do not object to your talking to her ſometimes, though I ſtrictly forbid your doing ſo to the other ſervants.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p:
We are perfectly convinced of the propriety of that. Indeed I cannot conceive how any one can wiſh it, their language is
ſo unpleaſant; and can one expect either pleaſure or improvement from thoſe who have had no education.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: Thoſe muſt have a very bad taſte who do.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Dear ma'am, is it nine o'clock?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: Yes, a full quarter after; what have you been doing?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Why ma'am, I aſked after breakfaſt what it was o'clock, and they ſaid it wanted a quarter of nine, ſo I thought I would ſet one of my drawers in order, but I did not begin directly, and I fancy that made me ſo late.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p:
Yes, moſt likely—your drawers generally require more than a quarter of an hour to ſet them to rights, and even of that quarter it ſeems you trifled away
part. If you would but conſider whether it is poſſible to do what you undertake in the time you can ſpare to it, you would not be ſo often behind your time.—And how have you left your cloaths now?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Oh ma'am, when Sally called me, I puſh'd them all into the drawer as well as I could.

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: (laughing.) Puſh'd them—yes, your things are generally pretty well puſh'd, as you call it!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: You have nothing to do with that.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: Come, come, leave off talking, and get to work—but remember I will have your drawer ſet to rights before you go out.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Oh I ſhall have plenty of time to do that.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p:
Aye!—that is exactly
your way!—You always have plenty of time in idea, and none in reality; of courſe you are always unpunctual.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: If I am, it is not a great fault.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Fye Laura!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: Is it not a great fault?—There I differ from you.—It leads to very unpleaſant conſequences at leaſt—often to very bad ones. In the firſt place, you trifle away a great deal of time: for inſtance, your ſiſters have been at work ſome minutes; of courſe their taſks will be done ſooner, and they will have the more time for other employments.—It is a chance if you are ready to go out with your mama: you have all your work to do; to read French, and to put your drawers in order.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Well, all that is my l • ſs▪

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: Your accent and manner are a little impertinent, but I will paſs that over, as I wiſh if poſſible, to convince you by reaſoning.—Suppoſe then, when you are older, you ſhould appoint a friend to meet you at any place, and becauſe you forget, or over ſtay your time, ſhe is diſappointed and has her trouble for nothing—That will be her loſs, I think!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Yes; but it would not be of much conſequence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: You are very ſlow to be convinced!—Suppoſe her buſineſs is of conſequence, and cannot be delayed!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Oh but I ſhould know that, and ſhould be ſure to be there.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p:
Very well! if you can all at once break thro' a ſettled habit, you have greater command
of yourſelf than I give you credit for.—You will ſee, and we ſhall learn, if you do not regret the many moments you have loſt in idle trifling.—When do you mean to begin work?
sp.stage: (Laura takes ſeveral pieces of work out of her bag.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: Why do you take out ſo much at once? you cannot do it all!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Which ſhould I do ma'am?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: This is what you left on Saturday, on promiſe to do it to-day; and this is your taſk for this morning, which I will have done.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: But there is ſo much!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: Not ſo much as I have given your ſiſters!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: But they are older!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p:
Yes, and ſomewhat
more induſtrious: there is not too much for you; ſo no more diſputing, but begin.
sp.stage: (Laura ſits down by Sophia. After a ſhort pauſe, ſhe yawns; then leans on Sophia's chair, and whiſpers to her, Sophia makes no anſwer.)

sp.speaker: Laura,
sp.p: (in a low voice.) Now pray do, Sophia!—You cannot think how much I ſhall be obliged to you.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Have done, Laura!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Huſh, don't ſpeak ſo loud!

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: I do not chuſe to whiſper!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: Pray what are you doing, Miſs Laura? Attend to your work, I beg of you; you are like all idle people, fond of diſturbing others.

stage.hi: (A ſhort pauſe, during which they work. When Mrs. Cecil is not obſerving her, Laura wraps her work round her thread papers like a doll, and jogs Eudocia.)

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Eudocia, look, look, I ſay, is not it droll?

stage.hi: (Eudocia looks up: tries to 〈◊〉 a laugh, but cannot. Mrs. Cecil looks towards them. Laura ſnatches up her work.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: How now, young ladies?

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: My ſtars, Laura, you are ſo ridiculous, you make me laugh!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: (laughing.) I!—'Twas the thread papers!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: Oh to be ſure! Have done, I charge you.—(Another pauſe, then Laura whiſpers Sophia.)

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Do pray be quiet, Laura, you are very teazing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: What is all this about?—Miſs Mildmay, what is ſhe ſaying?

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Aſking me, ma'am, to tell her ſomething I have refuſed to let her know twenty times already.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: She is very impertinent.—I ſhall remove you, Miſs Laura, if you torment your ſiſter ſo.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Becauſe it is ſo croſs, ma'am, it cannot be a ſecret, only ſhe chuſes to make it one on purpoſe to teaze me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: That is very likely—But no more of this.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Dear ma'am, it's ſomething ſo very odd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: Hold your peace.

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: What does ſhe want to know, Sophia?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I want to know what—▪

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: I inſiſt on your not ſpeaking.—You have all the faults of a Trifler, curious, impertinent, chattering.—I wiſh you could ſee how diſagreeable you make yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: Here comes mama.

div.stage: (They riſe.—The girls run and embrace their mother.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: Sit ſtill Mrs. Cecil.—My dear girls, how are you?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Quite well, mama, thank ye—are you well?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: Yes; tho' a little late this morning.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: You ſat late laſt night, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: Yes, the pleaſure of ſeeing my ſon detained me later than uſual.—How do your pupils behave, Mrs. Cecil?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: Vaſtly well, ma'am except a little—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: Laura, I ſuppoſe—you are conſcious, I ſee!—I too have a complaint to make.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Dear mama!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: Yes, I have indeed, but ſit down to your works.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Should I ſit, mama while you are ſpeaking to me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: No, my dear, I ſhall excuſe as much of your work as you would have done in the time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: As much as ſhe might have done, my dear Mrs. Cecil; what ſhe would have done is, I fancy, rather doubtful.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: Yes, indeed, ma'am.

div.p:
You look a little alarm'd, Laura, but I am not very angry with
you, ſince I believe your fault proceeded as uſual from want of thought.—Yeſterday, at church my dear, you behaved very ill.—In the firſt place, while we ſtood up, I ſaw your eyes wandering all over the church: in the next place, while we were ſitting, you whiſper'd to Eudocia, jogged her elbow, and tried to make her laugh.—Now, my dear, I beg you to conſider how very improper all this is.—Do you know for what purpoſe we go to church?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Yes, mama, ſurely, to pray to God.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: Well then, can you think ſuch behaviour proper?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: But it was not during the prayers.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p:
True, but part was during the pſalms, which are intended as immediate addreſſes to
our Creator, of both praiſe and prayer; therefore we ſtand to ſhow our reverence and attention.—When we were ſitting it was to hear the leſſons read; that is, ſelected parts of the holy ſcripture, the immediate word of God, and the the rule by which we are to direct our life.—Even if the ſervice had not been begun, or had been ended, to talk and laugh would have been highly improper.—It unfits the mind for ſerious duties, and implies a lightneſs and thoughtleſſneſs, which ought not to be indulged or allowed in a place ſacred to our maker.—Our Saviour ſhowed his diſapprobation of any thing which might diſturb the tranquillity and decency of the holy place, by driving from the Temple (the place of worſhip) at Jeruſalem thoſe whom human laws allowed to tranſact
buſineſs there, ſaying, "It is written, my houſe ſhall be called the houſe of prayer, but ye have made it a den of thieves."—I am ſure if you were in the Preſident's preſence, you would not be ſo ill-bred as to laugh and whiſper, when he was ſpeaking to you, or allowing another to do ſo; how much leſs then, when God ſpeaks to you by his ſcriptures, ought you to behave irreverently?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I am fully convinced, mama, I am much obliged to you for taking the trouble of inſtructing me▪ and, I aſſure you, I will never behave ſo aga •• .

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: I thank you alſo, mama, for I never ſaw this matter ſo clearly before.—I knew it was wrong to talk at church, but ſometimes I have forgotten it; now I think nothing will ever tempt me to do ſo again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: I am always happy, my children, to be of ſervice to you, and while I ſee you willing to be convinced and to amend, I am over paid for any trouble I can be at in inſtructing yo • .—Laura, return to your work.—At one o'clock, you will all be ready to go out; I ſhall not wait a minute for any-body, unleſs Mrs. Cecil can give me a good reaſon for the delay. Sophia, your brother will take you in his phae • on; our cold proviſions are all packed up.—I hope to hear a good account of you all: remember, that if you would enjoy the ride, and the • ight of the gardens we are to viſit, you muſt behave well.—Good-bye.—Mrs. Cecil, a good morning to you.—I hope you will like our ride.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p:
Yes, ma'am, I
have no doubt of it; a good morning to you.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Now, Mrs. Cecil, how much will you allow me, to leave of my work?

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: That is Laura's firſt concern?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: So it would be yours, if you had as much to do as I have.

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: I had as much at firſt.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: But mama has not been talking to you.

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: No, becauſe I behaved better yeſterday than you did.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Eudocia, when my mother is ſatisfied with the atonement for a fault, it does not become us to mention it reproachfully.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p:
Thank ye, Sophia, you ſeldom take my part, and Eudocia
deſerves a good lecture this time—however!

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: Then you think I do not often deſerve one?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
