sp.p: However that may be, you certainly de now.—Have done diſputing, Eudocia, that is your principal fault; you have been wrong all the way now you had, as your ſiſter obſerved, no right, nor was it kind, to reſume a ſubject your mama had done with; and to anſwer ſo ſharply and ſo often, ſhews an inclination to quarrel, very unpleaſant and improper.

sp.speaker: Eudocia,
sp.p: (after a ſhort pauſe.) It is very true, I have been wrong. Laura, I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Oh my dear, how good you are!—I am not angry!

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: How ſweetly was that ſaid!—How amiable is candour!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: Yes, indeed, I am pleaſed with Eudocia!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Well, nothing affects me like hearing any one ſay in that honeſt way, "I was wrong, I beg your pardon."—I never can help crying, and I feel ſo ſorry and ſo humble, and ſo pleaſed with them—But in ſpite of all that, I never can prevail on myſelf to aſk pardon; I feel ſo aſhamed, and ſo afraid of being laughed at!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p:
That is falſe ſhame.—No ſhame is juſt, but the ſhame of a bad or improper action; and as to being laughed at, the perſon who can laugh at another for doing as ſhe ought, muſt be unable to taſte the ſweetneſs of virtue, and the exaltation of humility.—But go on with your work, Laura: I ſhall allow you to leave off, when you have done ſo much,
(meaſuring her work.)—You have been ſadly idle. Eudocia, you may now read: bring that little book of manuſcripts your mama gave you on Saturday.

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p:
Yes, ma'am.—(She ſits down by Mrs. Cecil; takes a ſmall book, and reads.) "Come ye who love to ſee what is beautiful—come who wiſh to enjoy what is ſublime—come and I will direct your eyes to the bright Moon, which rides triumphantly on the boſom of heaven. Is ſhe not beautiful, when breaking thro' the black clouds which ſurround her, ſhe diffuſes ſplendour around!—Is ſhe not ſublime when ſinking beneath the • able veil, ſhe juſt tinges with lucid ſilver its unequal edges!—Again ſhe ſwells above the heavy vapour, and ſhines in perfect beauty. So riſes from the falſe
imputations of malicious ſlander, the undiminiſhed luſtre of true virtue. The machinations of evil men, the unavoidable concurrence of accident, may a while overſpread the beauty of a good name with heavy clouds, but its ſplendour ſhall return, and its enemies ſhall fly before it like the broken and disjointed track, which flies from the face of the Moon.—Comfort yourſelves, then, ye ſons of men: deſpair not, becauſe darkneſs, or even the ſhadow of death, ſurrounds you.—Time ſhall make manifeſt the beauty of goodneſs, and its ſoft luſtre ſhall diffuſe a ſweet and calm ſatisfaction into the boſoms of all who believed it."

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: That is very pretty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p:
The imitation of Mrs. Barbauld's hymn, "Come,
and I will ſhew you what is beautiful"—at the begining of this little piece, is obvious; but though inferior to that charming production, it is not without merit.—Read one more, Miſs Eudocia.

div.p:
How ſwiftly does imagination wing her flight!—Ere an inſtant has rolled over our head ſhe conveys us to the moſt diſtant quarter of the globe; ſhe repreſents to our mind the moſt remote events!—Time and diſtance fade before her, and her way is as unmarked as it is ſwift. We ſet out with one idea, and without being ſenſible of the progreſſive change, we find ourſelves meditating another.—Imagination then is like a voyager who, embarking on an immenſe river, is lulled by the found of the rippling water into a ſoft repoſe: he awake •
and finds himſelf in another country▪ the trees, the flowers, the whole face of nature is changed: perhaps he has in his ſlumber paſſed from the moſt gloomy ſcenes to the moſt enlivened, but he ſhudders in reflecting that he has probably alſo paſſed a tremendous fall or a lurking quickſand! In like manner the mind, wrapt in contemplation, may perhaps touch on the confines of ſome forbidden idea, ſome falſe principle, or ſcheme of gu ••• .—Happy thoſe who paſs them without harm; who do not indulge in ſuch imaginations, but, if they perceive them, ſtart aſide, and direct their courſe to a more deſirable climate."

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p:
Very well—that is ſufficient.—Now, Miſs Laura, bring me your Telemachus. Maintenant, Mademoiſelle
Laura, apportez moi
• o • re Telemaque.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Laura. Yes, ma'am. Oui, Madame.—(She riſes, loo •• in the book-caſe, then ſays) Oh dear, it is not here, 'tis upſtairs!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: How came it up ſtairs?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Mama deſired to hear me read while ſhe dreſs'd yeſterday and afterwards I took the book into my own room, and forgot to bring it down.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: Well, make haſte and fetch it; there is ſo much time loſt!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Oh I ſhall be back in a minute.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: What a careleſs child!

stage.hi: (Laura returns with the book; ſ • e ſits down and reads.)

sp.p: "Narbal me regardoit avec étonnement, et il crut appercevoi • en moi je ne ſcai quoi de hureux qui vient des dons du Ciel, et qui n'eſt point dans le commun des hommes: il etoit naturellement ſincère et genereux; il fut touché de mon malheur, et me p • rla avec • ne confiance, que les Dieux lui inſpirèrent pour me ſauver d'un grand peril, &c. &c.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: That is well read; now Miſs Mildmay you will tranſlate it.
sp.stage: (Laura returns to her work; Sophia takes her book.)
sp.p:
"Narbal regarded me with aſtoniſhment, and believed he perceived in me a certain expreſſion of goodneſs, which is the gift of Heaven, and is not common among men. He was naturally ſincere and generous; he was touched
with my misfortunes, and he ſpoke to me with a confidence which the Gods inſpired, to ſave me from imminent danger.—Telemachus, ſaid he to me, I neither do nor can doubt that which you tell me. The ſoftneſs and virtue painted on your countenance will not ſuffer me to ſupect you; I even feel that the Gods whom I have always ſerved love you, and decree that I ſhall regard you as my ſon. I will give you ſalutary con • els, and in return I only demand that you ſhall be ſecret.—Fear not, ſaid I to him, that I ſhall find any difficulty in concealing thoſe things which you confide to me. Though young, I am old in the habit of never revealing my own ſecrets, and ſtill leſs the ſecrets of others. How have you been able, ſaid he, in ſuch extreme youth, to accuſtom yourſelf
to ſecrecy: I ſhall be delighted to know by what means you have acquired that quality, which is the foundation of the wiſeſt conduct, and without which all talents are uſeleſs? When Ulyſſes, I replied, departed for the ſiege of Troy, he took me on his knees, holding me in his arms, (as I have been told) and after he had kiſſed me tenderly, he uſed theſe words, tho' I could not underſtand them. Oh! my ſon, may the Gods never ſuffer me to ſee thee again; rather let the fatal ſciſſars cut the thread of thy days ere it be half formed, as the reaper cuts down with his ſickle a tender flower as it begins to open; may my enemies daſh thee in pieces before the eyes of thy mother and myſelf, if thou 〈◊〉 doomed one day to be corrupted and to abandon virtue!—Oh'
my friends, continued he, I leave to you a ſon ſo dear: take care of his infancy. If you love me, baniſh from him pernicious flatterry; teach him how to conquer his paſſions, that he may be like a tender plant which men often bend in order to make it grow upright: above all, forget nothing which may render him juſt; benevolent, ſincere, and faithful in keeping a ſecret: whoever is capable of lying, does not deſerve to live; and whoever knows not how to be ſilent, is unworthy to govern. I repeat theſe words exactly; because care was taken to recount them to me frequently, and that they ſunk into the bottom of my heart."

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: Very well rendered indeed.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p:
This is a charming paſſage!—One ſees in the firſt
part of it, how agreable to all men is a candid open countenance, which can only be preſerved by retaining Truth in the heart.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: Yes, and the latter part is an excellent leſſon.—When you are diſpoſed to teaze your ſisters out of a ſecret, Laura, recollect this paſſage, and learn the neceſſity of a prudent reſerve.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: But Ulyſſes ſaid, whoever could not be ſilent was unworthy to govern, my ſiſters are not going to govern.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p:
I never ſaw a young lady more ingenious at finding objections. Theſe words were addreſſed to a young prince, therefore the word govern is uſed, but ſecrecy is a quality equally neceſſary in all ſituations, beſides, you may probably ſome time or other govern a family, though not a
kingdom, and believe me, you would find yourſelf very ill qualified to do that if you told your ſervants, your neighbours, and whoever would hear you, all the concerns of your houſhold, and every thing which came to your knowledge.—Have you done work, young ladies?—'Tis paſt twelve.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I have a little bit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: You muſt have been very idle, for I gave you very little.—You muſt dreſs, and ſet your drawer in order, ſo make haſte.
sp.stage: (Sophia and Eudocia riſe, fold their work and put it away.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p:
Laura, what's the reaſon your poor ſquirrel has
not been cleaned and fed?—I heard him very reſtleſs, looked at him, and found he had nothing to eat or drink.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Oh dear, mama, on Saturday I had not time, yeſterday I could not do it, and this morning, before breakfaſt, I had ſo much to do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: I told you then not to trifle ſo much time away, in putti • g on your cloaths. In the midſt of dreſ • ing, you took a fancy of reading two old letters, which you found in one of your drawers, then in ſpite of my remonſtrances you entirely new dreſſed your doll, and had only time to take half a turn in the garden, though your ſiſters and I walked a conſiderable time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p:
That is always the way. You will take improper
times to do things. You have no regularity, no idea how much time it will take to accompliſh ſuch and ſuch things.—When you had the ſquirrel, it was on promiſe to take care of it yourſelf; you ſhall not go out till he is fed.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: But, mama, I have not quite done work, I muſt put my drawer in order, and dreſs myſelf, I ſhall not be ready.—Mayn't Sally clean my ſquirrel's cage?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: No, ſhe ſhall not.—'Tis your own fault if you are not ready, and I will not indulge you in ſuch idle ways.—Let me hear what you have done ſince breakfaſt?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p:
Mama, I began putting my drawer to rights, which I had not time to finiſh: I have
read French, and hemmed all this muſlin.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: And you, Eudocia.

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: Mama, I made part of a paper-box, and wrote my journal in my pocket-book, before ſchool hour; and ſince I have read and worked this pattern of my frock.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: There, Laura, and all that in exactly the ſame time you have had?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Indeed, mama, I will manage better another time!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: Very well; at preſent however, you muſt do all you have to do.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Mrs. Cecil, ſhall we dreſs?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: Yes, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p:
I am dreſſed, therefore, Mrs. Cecil, I will take
care that Laura finiſhes her employments while you dreſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: Thanks to you, ma •••

sp.speaker: Laura▪
sp.p: Dear Mrs. Cecil, excuſe me this bit of work!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: No, Mrs. Cecil, I beg you will not!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: Indeed, ma'am, I am not at all diſpoſed to do ſo, unleſs you ſhould deſire it.
sp.stage: (Mrs. Cecil, Sophia, and Eudocia, go out.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Mama, I have done work.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: Very well; go then, and do all you have undertaken, and if you are ready, you ſhall go with me.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Mama, tell me what's o'clock?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: Half paſt twelve.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: And you go at one.—Well I think, I ſhall be ready.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: I think you will not.

div.head: THE LITTLE TRIFLER.
PART II.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Mildmay, meeting Mrs. Cecil, Sophia, and Eudocia.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay,
sp.p: WELL, Mrs. Cecil, are you ready? Where's Laura?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: Not ready, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: Then I ſhall not wait; ſhe deſerves to be left behind, and 'tis now ten minutes paſt one.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Mama, ſhe will be ready in five minutes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p:
No matter, it 〈◊〉 already paſt the time I had fixed;
we are to be at home by five, and we ſhall have barely time to ſee the gardens.—It is her own fault: let us go.

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: Oh I am very ſorry indeed Laura will not go!

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Ma'am, Miſs Laura begs you will be good enough to wait ten minutes; ſhe will be dreſsed in that time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: No, I will not▪ I have ſaid I will not, and ſhe knows I always keep my word. Come, Mrs. Cecil, come children. Sadly, tell Laura to confine herſelf to this room and the garden while we are gone; I will not have her running about among the ſervants.—Lay the cloth for her here.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p:
I am very ſorry for poor
Miſs Laura, ſhe will be ſo vexed!—But ſhe is always paſt her time.—To-day, truly, ſhe has been chattering to me inſtead of dreſſing, though ſhe knew her mama would not wait. "Oh I have plenty of time, it is not near one!"—that is her way.—Oh here ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Sally, do you know where my gloves are?—I am ready now!

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Ah miſs!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: What?—Bleſs me!—Sure mama is not gone!

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Indeed, miſs, I am ſorry to ſay ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: You jeſt, I am ſure!

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p:
No, truly miſs, I ſhould not take that liberty. Your mama would not wait a minute longer; both Miſs Mildmay and Miſs Eudocia tried to prevail on
her, but ſhe ſaid you knew ſhe never broke her word;

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: (with tears in her eyes.) You may go Sally.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Miſs, your mama ordered me to tell you, ſhe deſired you to to ſtay in this room.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Very well.
sp.stage: (Sally goes out. Laura draws a chair, throws herſelf into it: riſes again, and walks impatiently about the room.)

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p:
It is too bad, I declare!—To go without me; and to order me to ſtay in this room.—What is the reaſon of that, I wonder.—And George is gone with them. He goes away to-morrow.—This laſt day, which I thought to have ſpent ſo pleaſantly, to be ſo diſappointed.—'Tis very croſs in mama, I am ſure.—(She wipes her eyes.) I am always to blame: "Laura did this, Laura did that, Laura
is always wrong.—(She pauſes.) After all, I certainly might have been ready.—How did I dare ſay, mama was croſs.—What! mama, who is always ſo kind, ſo indulgent, ſo equal in her ſweetneſs of temper!—It was very wrong in me.—Dear mama, though you cannot hear me, I wiſh to aſk your pardon.—Well, what ſhall I do while they are gone?—How tedious the time is.—(A pauſe.) Lord bleſs me, I wiſh I might walk in the garden.—Perhaps mama ſaid I might: I will inquire—(She goes to the door, and calls) Sally!—Sally!

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Did you call, miſs?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Yes.—Did mama ſay I might walk in the garden?

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p:
Yes, miſs; I thought I had told you, this room and the garden.—My miſtreſs ſaid, you
ſhould not run about among the ſervants.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Oh that was the reaſon!—I am glad I know that.—Apropos, I wiſh I could find out this mighty ſecret of Sophia's.—Sally do you know it?

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: What, miſs?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p:
Why, I'll tell you. About a month ago, mama gave Sophia two guineas, and told her to buy whatever ſhe liked beſt with it. She gave one to Eudocia and one to me. Eudocia bought a ſmall writing deſk; and I bought a ſquirrel's cage, and ſome flower ſeeds for my garden: but Sophia ſaid ſhe would wait awhile and conſider before ſhe bought. Well, yeſterday it came into my head that ſhe had not bought any thing; and I aſked her what ſhe ſhould purchaſe with her two guineas.—
She coloured a little, and ſaid, "Oh ſomething I ſhall like."—Mrs. Cecil ſmiled, and I have never been able to get a more direct anſwer from Sophia.—Now, Sally, do you know what ſhe means to buy?

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Dear Miſs, is it likely I ſhould know?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: No, but you might nevertheleſs.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: And if I did, what advantage would it be to you to be told?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Oh then you do know!—Ah ha!—Come, my dear Sally, tell me, I pray you!

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: I did not ſay I knew▪ miſs.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Oh, but I am ſure of it.—Pray tell me.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p:
• ye miſs!—Conſider, if I did know, your ſiſter muſt
have told me in confidence; and do you think I would betray her?—Oh no, my good miſtreſs has taught me better!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Well, you know, however; ſo ſhe has determined on ſomething, that is one ſtep gained—I ſhall ſoon gueſs what!

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: But, Miſs Laura, who told you I knew?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Who?—yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: I!—that I could not!—I ſaid if, but it was only ſuppoſing!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: What then you don't know!

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: (laughing) That you ſhould really fancy Miſs Mildmay had told me!—Surely ſhe would have told you firſt!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: No, no, ſhe would not.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Why, miſs?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Becauſe ſhe thinks I ſhould tell.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Then you believe ſhe thinks I would not?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe ſo!

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: You 〈◊〉 me a great compliment, miſs; which I will try to deſerve.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Well, I cannot tell whether you know or not, but I have not 〈◊〉 you all.—Mrs. Cecil and Sophia have riſen half an hour earlier than common this laſt fortnight, and I wiſh I knew what for; I never could find out how they had employed themſelves.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Well, miſs, if I might venture to ſpeak, I ſhould ſay it was not worth taking ſo much trouble to know.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: If I think it is, that's enough.—I do not aſk your advice.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, miſs.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: You may go.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Let me conſider 〈◊〉 —What can Sophia warn to purchaſe—books 〈◊〉 has plenty, and mama is always buying fo •••• .—A box of colours.—She 〈◊〉 one.—New muſick—perhaps—but why make a ſecret of it!—Ah!—a locket of mama's hair! That muſt be it!—I dare ſay it is very pretty, and ſhe means to ſurpriſe us with it, I ſuppoſe!—But then what have Mrs. Cecil and Sophia been doing in the morning?—Oh, perhaps, they are painting a device for it.—Yes, yes, that is it!

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Miſs, there is a woman below ſtairs, in great diſtreſs; ſhe is very poor, and ſhe begs to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Well ſhew her up; I will ſpeak to her here.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Yes, miſs.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: What ſhall I be able to do for her, I have but half a crown, but I can ſpeak to mama.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: That is Miſs Laura.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Come in good woman.
sp.stage: (Sally goes out.—Ruth curtſies, and comes a little forward.)

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: What can I do for you?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Miſs I came to beg ſome relief from my lady, but your ſervants tell me ſhe is not at home, ſo I made bold to aſk leave to ſpeak to you, miſs.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Very well; what can I do to ſerve you?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p:
Alas aday, my young
lady, I am grievous poor; I am a widow, with three children, the eldeſt of 'em is out at ſervice, but the two little ones are too young to go out: my old mother lives with us; ſhe is helpleſs, and you may think, miſs, I find it hard to keep ſo many with the work of my own hands.—In the ſummer, I work in the fields: in the winter, I ſpin; and my children help me as well as they can. For two years, that my huſband has been dead, we have done pretty well, 'till this laſt winter.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: What happened then?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p:
Alas, miſs! in the autumn, I was ſo unhappy as to get an ague, which hindered my working a great deal; my children could do but little; they began to get dirty and ragged; it • ut me to the heart to ſee them ſo,
and not be able to help them!—To complete my misfortune, a dog got into my little garden, and killed my two hens, whoſe eggs uſed to furniſh us with a ſure penny. Things went from bad to worſe; I was fain to run in debt to my landlord, and tho' now the ſummer is coming on, and I am better, I hope I ſhould be able to pay him; the cruel man declares he will ſeize for rent to-morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: What is ſeizing for • ent.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Ah, miſs! he will take all our little cloaths and furniture, and the very beds we lye on, my poor old mother's and all, to ſell them, and pay himſelf.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Can he be ſo cruel!—Is he poor?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p:
No, miſs, he has four
hundred pounds a year, and only himſelf and his wife to keep.—What will become of my poor children, and my mother!—At ſeventy years old; muſt ſhe be turned out to ſtarve?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: (eagerly.) No, • o, ſhe ſhall not—be eaſy—I promiſe you ſhe ſhall not.—Poor, good woman, how I pity you—but what do you owe this unfeeling wretch?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Oh, good young lady, a great deal!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: But how much?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Thirty ſhillings, for half a year's rent.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Oh, how unfortunate I am!—If I had not ſpent my guinea, I ſhould have had almoſt enough; and perhaps he would have waited awhile.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p:
Ah, miſs, you are
very good!—but don't think I came here to beg my lady to pay for me; no, indeed, miſs I only thought if ſhe would ſpeak to my landlord, he would may-be wait a little; and indeed I hope I ſhall pay him every farthing.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I am ſure mama will do that and perhaps more. I will ſpeak to her for you good woman; make yourſelf eaſy, I will do all I can for you.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p:
Thank you a thouſand times, good young lady; we ſhall all pray for, and bleſs you. I have often ſeen your two ſiſters walking with Madam Cecil, and I have thought when Miſs Mildmay looked ſo kindly on my poor little girls, while they opened the gate for her, and ſaid with her ſweet voice, "Poor children, there's a penny for you."—I have
thought if ſhe did but know how wretched we were, ſhe would ſpeak to my lady for us; but I had not the heart to tell her, 'till now; things getting ſo bad, I thought I would try at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: You did very right.—Call again at ſix o'clock; I will ſee you, and before that I will ſpeak to mama, you may depend on it.—In the mean time, I will give you this half crown; I have no more.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: No, miſs, I thank you, I will not rob you; you will do all for me in ſpeaking to your mama.—She is ſo good, ſhe deſerves to have good children, and ſhe is rewarded!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: But I inſiſt on your taking this money; I wiſh it was more.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: It does not become me to refuſe your favors.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Take it, buy ſomething with it for your mother.—Good woman, I love you for being ſo kind to her! (She calls) Sally!

div.p: Take this good woman with you, and give her ſomething to eat: mama will not object to that.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: No, miſs, I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: And when ſhe comes again, let me know.—A good day to you.—Oh, tell me your name?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Ruth Saunders, miſs.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Very well, I ſhall remember.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Your ſervant, miſs, a thouſand thanks.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Well, I ſhall not regret being left at home, ſince it has been the cauſe of my ſeeing this poor woman.

div.p: Do you know that woman, Sally?

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Yes, miſs, I have ſeen her often; ſhe is very poor.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: So I hear—but why I wonder did ſhe never come hither before?

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Ah, miſs! 'tis very hard to beg; people who have been uſed to keep themſelves by their own induſtry, are aſhamed and afraid to aſk relief.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Aſhamed, perhaps; but why afraid?

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Becauſe, miſs, ſo many gentlefolks are croſs and hardhearted; and one ſays—"Where did you learn all that hiſtory," and another ſays, "Ah, a ſad ſtory, if it is true!"

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: But that is abominable if we don't chuſe to give, we need not inſult the poor creature who begs from us.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Very true, miſs, but too many don't think of that; they forget that a beggar has any feeling. I once ſaw a poor man colour like ſcarlet, and his eyes ſparkle with anger, at a gentleman, who ſaid he was an impoſtor; but, poor wretch, he recollected himſelf, put his hand on his boſom, ſighed and paſſed on.—I gave him a trifle; he bowed, and I ſaw the tears in his eyes; he did not ſpeak.—Poor creature, truly he was cut to the heart.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: You are a good girl, Sally—but tell me what you know of this poor woman?

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p:
Why, miſs, ſhe lives in a little cottage juſt at the end of the village, and keeps it very neat when ſhe is well; ſhe has two pretty children, and her mother (a good old woman) lives with her▪
the old woman is lame, but has all her ſenſes, and when dame Saunders was ſo ill, the poor old woman uſed to cry, and the little girls, thinking to comfort her, ſaid, "Don't cry grandmother, I will feed you, and put on your clean cap for you."

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Poor little dears!—how did you know this, Sally?

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Oh I heard • hem one day, miſs; when I was walking by the houſe, I ſaw the poor woman ſtanding at the door; ſhe look'd ſickly, ſo I aſked her a few queſtions, and found the ague was off that day, and ſhe had crept to the door for a little air.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: And when was this?

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: About a month ago, miſs.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: And why did you not t • ll mama?

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p:
I did, miſs, and my
miſtreſs ordered the cook to ſend her ſome broth twice or three times, and Miſs Sophia ſent her a ſhilling.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I never heard of that.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: No, miſs, becauſe Miſs Sophia never tells the good ſhe does.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: That is right, but I wonder I don't hear of it.—Indeed I never ſee any poor people; they don't come here, I fancy?

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: No, miſs, your governeſs and ſiſters find them out when they walk of a morning before breakfaſt.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: That may be, for I don't know how, I ſeldom have time to walk of a morning. Well, I will walk in the garden, and then learn my grammar-taſk; then, for once, I ſhall be beforehand.—Afterwards I will dine.—You will lay the cloth, Sally.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Yes, miſs.

div.p: Miſs Laura is very good; ſhe has an excellent heart, but ſhe is ſo light-headed and careleſs; 'tis a great pity, and I hope ſhe will break herſelf of it in time; no doubt ſhe will, for ſhe has very good ſenſe. Well, this room will do now.

div.head: THE LITTLE TRIFLER.
PART III.

p.hi: Mrs. Mildmay, Mrs. Cecil, Sophia, Eudocia, taking off their Cloaks and Hats, which they give to Sally.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: WHERE is Laura, Sally?

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Ma'am, ſhe is walking in the garden.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: Has ſhe dined

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: Well, call her hither directly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: We have had a delightful day indeed.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Very charming; and our little haſty dinner I enjoyed wonderfully.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: I never ate with better appetite in my life, than in the ſnug little cottage George found out for us.

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: I only wiſhed for Laura.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: That indeed was only wanting to make our party complete.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Oh, mama, are you returned; I did not expect you quite ſo ſoon.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: 'Tis paſt 〈◊〉 ; but, Laura, your brother has not ordered his phaeton from the door, having prevailed on me to ſuffer you to take a little ride with him.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p:
And ma •
〈◊〉
▪ mama?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 if you have behaved well 〈◊〉 we have been go • e.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Yes indeed, mama, I have only been in this room and the garden, and I have learned my grammar-taſk.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: Well, go then.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Yes, mama, thank you! thank you!—
sp.stage: (She runs a few ſteps; then returns, and whiſpers Sophia.)

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Pſhaw, nonſenſe!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Aye, but I have indeed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: Come, come, Laura, get your hat, and be gone; your brother waits.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Yes, mama—Good bye—Good bye, Mrs. Cecil, Sophia, Eudocia, your moſt obedient.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: What did ſhe ſay to you, Sophia?

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p:
〈◊〉 ſhe had diſcovered my 〈◊〉
•• ma.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: What does ſhe mean?

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: You know, mama, how I have diſpoſed of the two guineas you were ſo good as to give me▪ and Laura has been teazing me ſince yeſterday to know what I mean to buy: I refuſed to tell her, and ſhe fancies ſhe has gueſs'd it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: Silly child, how light her head is!

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: But perhaps ſhe really knows.—She may have learned from Sally, who bought my materials, and even aſſiſted in the work.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: No, I believe Sally is perfectly faithful.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: I believe ſo too.—We will aſk her preſently, if Laura has been queſtioning her.—But why did you ſo much object to Laura's knowing it, my dear.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Becauſe mama, Laura can no more keep a 〈◊〉 , than ſhe can let any one elſe keep it in peace, and I know ſhe would have told every-body ſhe had met with; which, for many reaſons, I wiſh'd to avoid.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: It is very true, that thoſe who are extremely curious, are generally unable to keep a ſecret, becauſe it gratifies their ſelf-importance, to ſhew that they know more than others, and becauſe they hope to obtain new ſecrets, in return for thoſe they tell: not conſidering, that a wiſe perſon will never place confidence in one who has abuſed the ſame truſt from another.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p:
There is nothing, I think, on which young people ought to be more ſcrupulous than on the ſubject of Confidence.—Let
them not be over-fond of ſeeking a truſt, which generally brings with it anxiety and care; but if by any accident, or any neceſſity, they find themſelves in poſſeſſion of a ſecret, they ought, with extreme delicacy and caution, to preſerve a truſt ſo ſacred.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p:
Moſt ſurely.—And the limits of Confidence are very ſtrict.—It is not only what our friends ſay, prefaced by "I beg you will not tell this," which we ought to conſider as confided to us. Every thing which we can ſuppoſe they would not wiſh revealed, we ought to conſider as told in confidence. Having once confided in a perſon, we do not ſay every minute, "don't mention that."—We ſuppoſe their own prudence will teach them what ought to be kept ſecret; and every thing is told
in confidence which paſſes between friends, either relating to their ſituations, ſentiments, or opinions; often, indeed, when referring to theſe circumſtances in others.

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: Mama, I have heard people ſay, that we ought not to tell to one friend what another has told us.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: Certainly not. The perſon who confides in you may not have an equally good opinion of your friend, or circumſtances may render it very improper to entruſt her. You may not be able to judge of theſe circumſtances; therefore you ought to be as reſerved to her as to the reſt of the world: beſides, ſhe alſo might have a friend, to whom ſhe might not ſcruple to tell the ſecret; that friend another, and ſo on without any bound.

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: I ſee that very clearly.—But ſuppoſe I ſhould, know the perſon who entruſts me is alſo very intimate with my friend, and loves her, might I not then talk about the affair with her?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p:
No, not without leave from the perſon who entruſts you; if ſhe chuſes to tell this third perſon, ſhe can; if not, you may be ſure ſhe has ſome reaſon againſt it. I lately read a ſtory exactly in point.—When Gen. Monk projected the Reſtoration of Charles the IId. he maintained the ſtricteſt reſerve on the ſubject, even to his friends.—He ſent, however, for his brother, Dr. Monk, intending to confide his plan to him, and even giving him ſome hints reſpecting it.—When Dr. Monk arrived, while waiting for admiſſion to the General, he entered into
converſation with the General's Chaplain, in whom he knew he confided and talked with him on the plan.—When he was admitted to his brother, the General aſked him if he had mentioned the ſubject to any one?—"To nobody," ſaid the Doctor, "but to your Chaplain, whom I know you truſt."—The General immediately changed countenance, dropped the diſcourſe and ſoon after ſent his brother away; not chuſing to truſt a man who had talked on a ſubject of ſo much conſequence to another, even tho' he would himſelf have truſted him
〈◊〉 Hun •• 's Hiſtory of England.. A proof of his wiſdom; for ſurely Dr. Monk had evidently ſhewed a want of delicacy in his ſe ••• ments, which rendered
him u •• it to have the care of a plan ſo important!

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: I admire the General's conduct extremely.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p:
He was undoubtedly right. The faculty of keeping a ſecret is highly neceſſary, yet rarely poſſeſſed. I made Laura remark that admirable paſſage in Telemachus to-day, becauſe I remember the effect it had on myſelf.This is abſolutely fact, of a child well known to the Author. Always fond of reading, Telemachus fell early into my hands: I was not above eight years old when that paſſage ſtruck me; I reflected on it, and it has influenced my conduct ever ſince. Such indeed has been the conſtant advantage I have derived from books.—My mother died •• ung:
and my father, encumbered with the care of a family, left us in great meaſure to educate ourſelves. I was naturally very paſſionate, very idle, fond of beginning every thing, and ending nothing; but with a conſtant fondneſs for ••• ding, which in the end ſupplied to me the place of an inſtructor.—The ſame author, I have always loved ſo much, ſays in another placeHappy thoſe who are amuſed by Inſtruction, and take delight in cultivating their minds by Science. Into whatever ſituation unkind Fortune may caſt them, they carry always with them the means of converſation. And that fatiguing Idleneſs, which devours ſo many, even in the midſt of Pleaſure, is unknown to them who know how to employ themſelves in reading.—Happy thoſe who love to read!" "Heureux ceux qui ſe divertiſſent
en s'intruiſant, et qui ſe plaiſent à cultiver leur éſprit par les ſciences! En quelque endroit que la fortune ennemie les jette, ils portent • o • jours avec eux dequoi s'entretenir Et l'ennui, qui devore les 〈…〉 au milieu même des delices, • ſt inconnu à ceux qui ſavents' occuper par quelque lecture. Heureux ceux qui aiment à lire."—When I ſaw any very amiable character repreſented in my books, I conſidered whether I had, or wanted the qualities I admired ſo much. This was often a moſt unpleaſant taſk, but I obliged myſelf to perſevere in the inquiry; and having decided, tried to act accordingly.—When I read of any diſagreeable character, and my heart told me I had its faults, I did not drive the conviction from me, but tried to correct myſelf.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: An admirable example, and well worthy of being followed by thoſe young people whoſe parents are either dead, or ſo engaged in buſineſs, as not to be able to attend to them: ſuch young people would do well to obſerve the convictions of their own heart, and reaſon, and follow them, not refuſe to liſten to them.

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: I have often heard people ſay, it is of no uſe to read without reflection; but I never quite underſtood what was meant 〈◊〉 reflection, before. However, we are very happy in having a mother and governeſs ſo well able to inſtruct us.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p:
Very true, you have great advantages; but, that does not render reflection leſs neceſſary to you: without it, our
precepts will be ſoon forgotten; and when you come to act for yourſelf, you will look round for thoſe rules by which indeed you have been guided, but which you have neglected to implant in your heart; and miſſing them, you will no more know how to act in the world, than a man to find his way thro' a wood, which he had often ſeen at a diſtance, but whoſe particular ſituation he had neglected to mark.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Pray, ma'am, is Miſs Laura here?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: No, Sally, ſhe is gone out with her brother.—Why; do you want her?

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p:
Ma'am, there is a poor woman below, who came while you were out: ſhe ſaw Miſs Laura,
who deſired her to call again at ſix o'clock.—It is ſix o'clock now.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: Yes, but Laura has ſurely forgotten the appointment!—Idle child!—ſhe will never learn to be punctual.—Where is the woman? I will ſee her.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: She is down ſtairs, ma'am. It is Dame Saunders.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Indeed!—then perhaps—but ſhe kn • w nothing of it: ſo Laura could not learn from her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: What, is it the woman for whom your gift was intended!

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Yes, mama.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: Sally, did Laura queſtion you about the purchaſe Miſs Mildmay meant to make with her two guineas?

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p:
Yes, ma'am, but I told her nothing; indeed ſhe does not
know that I know any thing about it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: That is right,—Come with me, Sophia; we will talk to the poor woman.
sp.stage: (Mrs. Mildmay, Sophia, and Sally go out)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: How ſhameful for Laura to have neglected an appointment; on which, probably, the peace and happineſs of this poor woman depended!—And to have been ſurpaſſed by her ſervant in faithfulneſs and ſecreſy!—All her faults proceed from carleſſneſs, inattention, and want of punctuality.—Great vices, as well as great virtues, are rare; but it is thoſe errors, which ſeem at firſt trifling, but which grow upon us by degrees, of which we ought principally to beware.

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: But, Mrs. Cecil Laura is ſo young.

sp.speaker: Mrs Cecil.
sp.p: Yes, ſhe is young; but, with the advantages ſhe has, ſhe ought to know better: however, ſhe has a good heart and underſtanding▪ and, I hope, ſhe will correct herſelf.

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: Oh yes, I hope ſo!

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Oh, Mrs. Cecil, mama has rendered this poor woman ſo happy 〈◊〉 —She has been in the greateſt diſtreſs about her rent: mama has given her money to pay it, and money to buy food and cloaths. I have deſired her to wait, while Sally fetches down the box I deſign for her▪—Will you go with me, and give it to her?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: Pray, ſiſter, let me go alſo.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: My dear, I ſhould be happy to do ſo; but I wiſh very much you would be kind enough to ſtay in this room. Laura will be at home in a few minutes; if ſhe finds no one here, ſhe will follow us; and mama is determined to puniſh her, for neglecting this poor woman, by leaving her in doubt whether ſhe has been here or not.

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: Very well—I will call with you, then, to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p:
If you pleaſe; you oblige me extremely by this compliance.—Only think, Laura had promiſed Ruth Saunders to repreſent her ſituation to mama, and to give her the anſwer at ſix o'clock.
She forgot all that!—but ſhe gave her all the money ſhe had; and Ruth ſaid, behaved ſo kindly to her, as to make her quite happy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: How capable ſhe is of behaving well, if ſhe does but think!

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: It is very true, indeed, that a habit of careleſſneſs injures one extremely.—Laura this morning could not believe ſhe ſhould ever neglect an appointment of conſequence.—Oh here ſhe comes!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p:
So, Eudocia!—Where are mama and Mrs. Cecil; and Sophia, I don't ſee her either!—We have had a charming ride! My brother was very good to take me out, and he has been telling
me ſuch delightful things about the • ights in Philadelphia; he promiſes to aſk mama to let me go next autumn, and ſee them.—Shall you not wiſh me to go, Eudocia?

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: To be ſure; why do you think I would not?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Oh, becauſe you looked ſo grave.

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: Did I look grave?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Yes, I think ſo.—Have you drank tea?

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: No: of courſe we ſhould wait for my brother.
And for me, I hope you think I am of conſequence enough to be waited for!

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: (ſmiling.) What do you think?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Ah you •• y girl!—I know what you 〈◊〉 : 'tis true, mama did not think ſo this morning.

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: I aſſure you, we all wiſhed for you.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Oh I don't doubt it at all. I ſhall be more punctual another time; for tho' I liked my ride, it did not make amends for loſing ſo much pleaſure.—And George muſt go to-morrow: he ſays it will be a month before he comes again.—How good he is; how I love him!

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: How we all love him—He is ſo attentive to us all!—Oh here comes Sophia.

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: Sophia, what are you come 〈◊〉 ?

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Yes, I have been extremely •• lighted!

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: Was • he pleaſed?

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Oh 〈…〉 one ſo happy▪

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: So! ſo!—More ſecrets—Ah ha Sophia!—I have found out the laſt however!—Another time, I hope, you will truſt me!

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Not the ſooner becauſe I find you curious, and prying into what I wiſh to hide from you.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Well, but my little Sophia, my dear ſweet Sophia, don't be angry; you know I could not help gueſſing!

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: You gueſs'd, did you?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Yes, I gueſs'd: well, Sophia, is it very beautiful?

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Oh, very beautiful, if one did but know what you meant.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: You don't then, I ſuppoſe?—Is the device handſome?

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: The device!—What nonſenſe!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: What, then, I ſuppoſe you will not own you have purchaſed a locket, with mama's hair?

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: You have a fine gueſs, indeed!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: A true one, I fancy?

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: For once, you are entirely miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: What can it be then!—Now, Sophia, do tell me.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Perhaps—

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Oh do, pray do; indeed I will not tell.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: I wiſh I had more reaſon 〈◊〉 truſt your 〈…〉 however, 'tis no longer 〈◊◊〉 , ſo, if you wiſh it, I will tell you.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Oh yes, yes, make haſte, Sophia, make haſte!

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p:
You muſt know then, that, during the winter, I obſerved two pretty little girls, in the village, almoſt without cloaths: I pitied them very much, and wiſhed I could relieve them. I began by ſaving all I could out of my allowance,
and had already ſome ſhillings in advance, when mama gave me the two guineas: with her leave, I laid it out entirely in cloaths for the two little girls, and their mother, of whoſe diſtreſs I heard ſad accounts.—Mrs. Cecil, Sally and I, have been hard at work in making theſe cloaths, whenever we could find time, and all is now finiſhed.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: So, then, Sally knew!

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: She would not tell!

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: What, you tried to make her?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I aſked her—a little.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Fye, fye, Laura!—You muſt have ſuppoſed ſhe knew in confidence, if ſhe knew at all! Only think what a ſhame, that your ſervant ſhould know better how to act with reſpect to ſecreſy than you.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Well, that is true; but, Sophia, who are theſe little girls?

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Their mother's name is Ruth Saunders.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Ruth Saunders!—Oh goodneſs!—Is it ſix o'clock?

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Six!—'tis almoſt ſeven!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Oh, where is mama!—Let me ſee her directly!—Where is Sally?

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: Dear Laura.

sp.speaker: Sophia,
sp.p: (aſide to her.) Huſh—What's the matter, Laura?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Oh, don't aſk me!—I am aſhamed of myſelf; tell me where is mama.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Mama is buſy; you cannot ſee her.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Oh, I muſt, I muſt!—Sally! Sally.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Oh, Eudocia, how I feel for her!

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: I can hardly bear to ſee her ſo unhappy.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Mama has commanded ſilence!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Sally! Sally!—why don't you come.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Miſs!—Bleſs me, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Sally, has Ruth Saunders been here?

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Yes, miſs.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p:
Without ſeeing me!—What muſt ſhe think of me!—It is almoſt dark too!—I ſhall not be able to ſee her to-night, and to-morrow!—Oh, poor creature, how unhappy ſhe is.—But if I can
ſee mama, it may not be yet too late!—Dear Sophia, if you have any love for me, aſk mama to let me ſee her!—I have ſomething of great conſequence to ſay.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Indeed, my dear girl, it grieves me to refuſe you, but mama has forbidden me to interrupt her.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: How can you be ſo unkind!—Indeed it is very cruel, and you ſeem not to feel for me.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Believe me, my dear, I feel for you very much.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Why then will you not intercede for me?

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: I have told you already, that mama—

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Oh mama would hear me, if ſhe knew—but how we loſe time!—It will be too dark, and I ſhall be too late.—Eudocia will you aſk mama to let me ſee her?

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: I hear her coming.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Oh then I may ſtill ſucceed!

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Mildmay, and Mrs. Cecil.

sp.speaker: Laura,
sp.p: (running to Mrs. Mildmay.) Mama, dear mama, will you have the goodneſs to hear me!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: What would you ſay?—Why this extreme agitation?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p:
Oh mama, while you were gone, a poor woman came hither: ſhe wanted relief from you; I ſaw her, I promiſed to intercede for her, and give her the anſwer at ſix o'clock.—Her landlord has threaten'd to take all her goods for rent to-morrow morning. She hopes I ſhall prevail on you to plead for her to him. Deareſt mama, will you grant me this
favour? Indeed ſhe deſerves your goodneſs!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: How do you know that?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Becauſe, mama, ſhe told me all her ſtory: ſhe has been ſick; ſhe has two children, and an old mother.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: But, Laura, it is eaſy to ſay all that; nay, it may be true, and yet ſhe may be idle and undeſerving. You know I never exert myſelf but in favour of worthy objects. I have now no time to inquire, 'tis paſt ſeven, and very near dark; can I learn the truth of this ſtory to-night?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: But, mama, to-morrow will be too late.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: Why then did you not tell me the ſtory ſooner?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I intended to do ſo, as ſoon as you came home, mama, but—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: But you forgot it!—Is it not ſo?—You choſe the pleaſure of a ride, rather than the gratifying theſe poor people:—Thus you have loſt, from your careleſſneſs and unpunctuality, an opportunity of doing a good action, of making a whole family happy, and of increaſing my love for you!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Oh, mama, I have been ſadly to blame indeed, but I aſſure you this ſhall be the laſt time. Only hear me this once!—try what you can do for this poor woman; Sally knows her, nay Sophia kn • ws her: inquire of them!—Puniſh me as you pleaſe, but do not puniſh her for my fault!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p:
Only imagine this poor creature's diſappoinment when told you were not at home. Think of her diſtreſs: ſhe had then loſt her only hope!—See her returning
to her cottage, where ſhe had left her mother and children anxious for the ſucceſs of her petition; hear her with tears ſay, "Ah my children, we muſt be ruined; the perſon who promiſed us aſſiſtance has forgotten us!—She i • gone out; ſhe has not mentioned us to her mother, and to-morrow we ſhall be turned out to ſtarve!"

sp.speaker: Laura
sp.stage: Oh, mama, I implore you to ſave me from being the cauſe of this miſery!—Indeed, I am cured for ever of my folly; I will never be trifling, inconſiderate, and unpunctual again!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay,
sp.p:
Promiſes of amendment do not prove any thing, yet I muſt hope this leſſon will reach your heart!—If I were as i • conſiderate as you
all the ſad conſequences I have deſcribed to you would be realized, and even all I can do will hardly efface from the mind of this poor woman the anguiſh ſhe ſuffered when told you were gone out, and had not mentioned her to me.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Then, mama, you will be good enough to aſſiſt her?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay
sp.p: Certainly I will; your breach of promiſe can be no reaſon why I ſhould fail in my duty: but if. I had waited till I heard the ſtory from you, it would really have been too late for me to do any thing in it, as I could not have learned all I wanted to know at this time.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Had you then heard it before?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p:
Yes; Sally, not finding you, came to me. I ſaw the poor woman; heard her
ſtory, and having had • eaſon before to believe it, I relieved her. Sophia has given her a box of cloaths, and ſhe is gone home perfectly happy.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Oh, mama, how good you are to every body!—Indeed, you may believe, I will profit by this leſſon. I can never again run ſuch a riſk of making any one miſerable.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cecil.
sp.p: You muſt then break yourſelf of the habit of trifling; for you ſee now, as I told you this morning, it cannot be diſmiſſed at once, whenever it is of conſequence it ſhould be!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p:
Oh, it is true, indeed!—even, at leaſt, when I came home if I had not trifled away the time, by aſking Sophia impertinent queſtions, I ſhould have found it leſs impoſſible to ſerve this poor woman!
—dear Sophia, I will never teaze you again.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Believe me, it hurt me extremely, to keep the truth from you, when I ſaw you ſo diſtreſſed; but mama had commanded me not to tell you.

sp.speaker: Eudocia.
sp.p: As to me, I was on the point of telling.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Mama, do you forgive me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p:
I forgive you, hoping you will correct yourſelf, and that you now ſee the fault, you thought ſo trifling, is really of ſerious conſequence: but altho' I am no longer diſpleaſed, I ſhall inflict a puniſhment in addition to that which you have already ſuffered. I ſhall not permit you to have any ſhare in the farther aſſiſtance we mean to give this poor woman; nor to call on her with your ſiſters
for a full fortnight; if, in that time, I ſee any inſtance of unpunctuality in your conduct, I ſhall extend the time as long as I think proper.—So you will loſe the pleaſure of ſeeing her happineſs, and the joy of her old mother and children, for the gift Sophia has made them!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Oh, mama, this is indeed a puniſhment—but I deſerve it!—However, I hope—I am ſure I ſhall ſee her at the end of the fortnight!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mildmay.
sp.p: I hope you will.—But 'tis late.—Let us go down ſtairs to tea.—And let this occurrence teach us all never to forget our promiſe,, or let any gratification tempt us to neglect our poſitive engagements.

figure.head: Little Country Visitor. Laura's Visit to the Young Montforts.

q.l: Accompliſhments by Heaven were firſt deſign'd
Leſs to adorn than to amend the mind.

list.head: CHARACTERS.
list.item: Maria, —A young woman under Mrs. Montfort's care.

div.head: THE Little Country Viſitor.
div.stage: Mrs. Montfort and Maria, at work.—Matilda and Harriot at a window; one dreſſing a doll, the other playing with a bandalore.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: HARRIOT, don't you think my doll looks very pretty in this bonnet?

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: Yes; I wiſh you would make me ſuch a one.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Oh, to be ſure!—No indeed!—Why don't you make yourſelf one?

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: But I don't know how.—Well, if you won't, Maria will; won't you Maria?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: What, my dear?

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: Make my doll a bonnet, like Matilda's?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: —Perhaps—

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: Oh, only perhaps—

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: You know, Miſs Harriot, it muſt depend on whether you behave properly, and whether your mama chuſes it to be done.

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: Oh, but I will behave properly, and then mama will chuſe it to be done.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort.
sp.p: We ſhall ſee that.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: I ſhall make my doll ſo many things this ſummer; we ſhall have ſo much time in the country.

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: Not ſo much time truly!

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: But we ſhall!—The days will be very long, and we ſhall get up early.

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: Yes, but then we ſhall run in the garden, and plant flowers, and that will take up our time.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: How ſhall we plant flowers?—We don't know how, nor when to water them.

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: Oh, James will tell us.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Well, I wiſh Miſs Roſetta would come. I ſuppoſe ſhe is pretty ſtupid!

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: Oh, and ſo awkward!—I dare ſay ſhe hangs down her head, and won't ſpeak, like thoſe little girls we ſaw when we were in Worceſter.

sp.speaker: Matilda,
sp.p:
Oh dear!—How droll they uſed to be. They uſed to curtſey, juſt ſo, (mimicking)
and ſay, yes, miſs; if you pleaſe, miſs!—and they were ſo ignorant too!

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: Dear, yes!—They did not know how to dance, nor to draw, nor to do fine work.—What ſtupid children!

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Now you have made me think of them, I ſhall laugh if Miſs Roſetta ſhould be like them.—Harriot, don't make me laugh when ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: Don't you make me laugh.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: But—Miſs Harriot.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort, (to her.)
sp.p: Huſh—let them alone—this will be a leſſon for them—they think I don't hear.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Mama, did you ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort.
sp.p: Yes to Maria.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p:
When will this girl
come?—I dare ſay ſhe is afraid—ſhe thinks ſhe ſhall look awkward.

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: I fancy ſhe is not much miſtaken!
sp.stage: (A rap is heard at the parlour door.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort.
sp.p: Pray come in.—Matilda open the door.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Oh dear mama, (laughs.)—Harriot, have done laughing.
sp.stage: (Roſetta comes in, ſhe curtſies modeſtly. Her dreſs and manner ſhould be plain, but not awkward. Matilda and Harriot ſtare at her, and ſtifle a laugh.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort.
sp.p: Come in, my dear. I am very glad to ſee you, How do your father and mother?

sp.speaker: Roſetta:
sp.p: Very well, thank you, ma'am; they deſired their reſpects to you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort.
sp.p:
I am very
much obliged to them.—Matilda, come and ſpeak to Miſs Roſetta, and take her bonnet.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: To wait upon her indeed.
sp.stage: (She advances affectedly and proudly towards Roſetta.)
sp.p: How do you do, ma'am? I am glad to ſee you.—Give me leave to take your cloak.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Thank you, ma'am; pray don't trouble yourſelf.
sp.stage: (Matilda takes away her cloak, &c. laughing aſide at Harriot.—Roſetta ſees them, bluſhes, and looks uneaſy.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort.
sp.p: It is a fine day, Miſs Roſetta.—The country begins to look very pleaſant.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort.
sp.p: What ſays your father to the preſent appearance of the corn?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: He thinks it promiſes very fair, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort, (to Matilda.)
sp.p: Why don't you go and talk to Miſs Roſetta.—I am aſhamed of you.

sp.speaker: Matilda, (in a low voice.)
sp.p: Dear mama, what ſhould I ſay to her?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort.
sp.p: Fye, you ſilly child!—Maria come with me, I am going to dreſs; and by the time I return, I hope young people you will be better acquainted. Matilda, do all you can to amuſe Miſs Roſetta. Harriot, be ſure you behave properly.
sp.stage: (A long pauſe, during which all the children look confuſed.)

sp.speaker: Harriot, (to Matilda.)
sp.p: Why don't you ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Matilda, (aloud.)
sp.p: Be quiet, Harriot, you are the moſt provoking child!

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: Child!—to be ſure!

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: What, you think yourſelf a woman, I ſuppoſe, at nine years old!

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: Why not, as well as you at ten?

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Such nonſenſe!—Miſs Roſetta, will you like to look at my books?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: If you pleaſe, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Harriot,
sp.p: Is not this a very pretty thing?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: Will you play with it?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: I don't know how.

sp.speaker: Harriot,
sp.p: There you muſt let it fall, and then jerk the ſtring a little—you ſee it winds up; there, you muſt keep it up.

sp.speaker: Roſetta,
sp.p: Is that right▪

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: Yes, very right; you will ſoon do it. O, but you muſt not jerk it ſo much.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: What do you call it, pray?

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: A bandalore; ſome call them, Prince of Wales's toys.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Oh, don't you know?—They are all the faſhion. The Prince of Wales brought them in.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: They are pretty, but there is no great ingenuity in playing with them, I think.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Oh no, it is all a knack.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: I like better a play, thing which requires more ſkill, or elſe is an exerciſe.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: So do I.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: But you ſaid, ma'am, you would ſhew me your books.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: So I will—(To Harriot.)—She ſpeaks prettily.

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: Yes, ſhe does not ſeem ſtupid.

sp.speaker: Roſetta, (looking at the books.)
sp.p: Oh, here is the Friend of Youth, and the Tales of the Caſtle.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Yes, can you read them in French.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: No, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Oh, they are charming in French.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: I dare ſay they are.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Should you not like to learn French?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Yes, but my father ſays it is not proper for me.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Do you learn to dance?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: No, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Dear, not to dance!—oh, that is beſt of all; I love dancing. Harriot, let us dance Mr. Duport's Cadrille. Shall you like to ſee us?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: If you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Now the Scotch ſteps Harriot.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Oh! I am out of breath—I love the Scotch reels, and they are very faſhionable now.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: It is very pretty indeed, and you dance vaſtly well.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Oh no, you flatter me!

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: No indeed—I hope you have not ſo bad an opinion of me.—Perhaps, indeed, I am no judge.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Oh yes, I dare ſay you are.

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: Yes, becauſe ſhe admires your dancing!

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Harriot, you are very impertinent.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Oh, Miſs Harriot only jeſts.

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: Not I, Indeed!

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Very well, miſs, I ſhall tell mama.

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: As you like it.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: But, Miſs Matilda, here is another book, which ſeems very pretty. Is it pretty?

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Which do you mean?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Mrs. Barbauld's Hymns.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Oh, that is a child's book, and ſo grave!

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: A child's book!—why mama is very fond of it, and ſays it is beautiful.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: I ſhould like to read it.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Oh, I'll lend it to you.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: I ſhall be extremely obliged to you.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p:
Oh, you'll be very
welcome.—Pray do you learn to ſing?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: No indeed.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Your education ſeems to be very confined.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: You know I am only a farmer's daughter.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: There is ſomething in that to be ſure. I ſuppoſe, if you learn how to make butter, and ſell eggs, your father is ſatisfied?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Not entirely with that.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: I learn to ſing.—Do you love ſinging?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Yes, indeed very much.

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: Matilda wants to be aſked to ſing.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Harriot, you are exceſſively impertinent.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: I am ſure I ſhall be happy to hear you.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Oh, indeed, I am very hoarſe.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Pray then don't trouble yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Nay, to oblige you, I'll try.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Very pretty, indeed.—That is a charming ſong.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: I declare, Miſs Roſetta, you have a great deal of taſte.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Have I?

sp.speaker: Matilda,
sp.p: How ſimple ſhe is!

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: I like her very well.

sp.speaker: Matilda,
sp.p: But if you neither dance nor ſing, how do you contrive to fill up your time?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Oh, I have a great deal to do.

sp.speaker: Matilda,
sp.p: I ſuppoſe ſhe milks the cows!

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: No, Miſs Matilda, I don't.

sp.speaker: Matilda,
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: You thought I did not hear you!

sp.speaker: Matilda,
sp.p: I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Oh, I am not angry; if you are amuſed, that is enough.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: You are extremely good—I did not mean—

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: You did not mean to offend me. I know that one ought not to be angry at a jeſt.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: You are very obliging.

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: Now, Matilda, you are fairly caught; it ſerves you right.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Harriot, I did not aſk you to interfere.
sp.stage: Mrs. Montfort and Maria come in.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort.
sp.p: So, young people!—Heyday, Matilda, what's the matter?—You look confuſed.—What have you been doing?

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Nothing, mama.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort.
sp.p: Oh, don't tell me that, I know better.—What was it?

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: Mama, ſhe ſpoke impertinently of Miſs Roſetta.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort.
sp.p:
Harriot, that is a great fault, but it is a greater to be ſo eager to accuſe your ſiſter. My children, learn, that if you fail to conceal and excuſe the errors of each other, the world will ſtill more eagerly publiſh, and ſtill more bitterly condemn them.—Where, alas! ſhall thoſe who are faulty, look for pity and forgiveneſs, if not to thoſe kindred boſoms who, knowing their failings, know alſo their virtues.—If we ourſelves point the arrows of ſatire and reproach, at our ſiſters and our friends, who will hold before them the
ſhield of allowance and pardon!—This is not, however, intended to excuſe you, Matilda. I am ſorry, indeed, to hear you have behaved ill.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Dear ma'am, indeed it was a mere jeſt, a trifle, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort.
sp.p: Very well, my dear, if you are ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Yes, indeed, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Matilda,
sp.p: It is more than I deſerve.—Mama, I was very much to blame.—I aſk your pardon Roſetta.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Indeed, Miſs Matilda, I am not offended. I am ſorry to have cauſed you any uneaſineſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort.
sp.p: You are a very good girl. I hope both your companions will profit by your example.—Let us go to dinner.

div.head: The Little Country Viſitor.
PART II.
div.stage: Matilda, Harriot, and Roſetta, enter from the houſe.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: YOU will like our garden, I think, Miſs Roſetta; it is very pleaſant, and you cannot imagine how we enjoy it, after being ſo long in Philadelphia.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: I imagine you were very much confined there.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p:
Yes, indeed.—You know we lived in Cheſnut-Street; every morning, before breakfaſt; we walked with our governeſs,
and Maria, up and down the ſquare for an hour.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: The ſquare—but is it like a garden?

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Oh, no, there are houſes on every ſide, and where we walk is only a pavement; ſo it is merely for exerciſe, and tireſome enough I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: Oh, but you know ſometimes we went to the State-Houſe.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Oh, the State-Houſe—yes, that is very fine to be ſure.—There we have a long gravel walk, with trees on each ſide, and full of people.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: What! no graſs walks?—nor flowers?

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Flowers!—Oh no, you might look for ſeven years without finding one.—And on the graſs we muſt not walk.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Oh dear how ſad!—I ſhould hate that.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Oh yes, it is frightful indeed.—Sometimes we went to Harrow gate-gardens, which are charming, but not often.—Well, now we are in the country, we ſhall walk a great deal.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: We have charming walks.—If Mrs. Montfort will give me leave, I will ſhew them to you.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Oh, thank you, we ſhall like that vaſtly.

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: Perhaps too you know how to plant flowers, and manage them.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: I have a large piece of garden, which I keep in order.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: What, all yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p:
No, the man digs it, and puts it in order; I ſow the feeds, water them, tie up the flowers
when they are blown, and do all that is not very fatiguing.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: How very agreeable!—What flowers have you?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Honeyſuckles, roſes, carnations, ſtocks, and a great variety of others, and alſo a large bed of thyme for my bees.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Your bees!—Have you bees alſo?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Oh, yes, three hives.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Oh, charming!—You are not afraid of them?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Dear no!—I never diſturb them, and they do not hurt me.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Are they troubleſome to keep?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Not at all. I have only to give them a little honey in the winter, to obſerve when they are going to ſwarm, and to provide a hive.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: To ſwarm—what is that?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: When the hive becomes too full, a great number of young bees go out of it, to find another place, where they make their comb and put the honey.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Where do they get the honey?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: From the flowers. They ſuck it out with a ſort of trunk; in paſſing through their bags it becomes honey. They alſo roll themſelves in t •• yellow duſt of flowers, which makes the wax.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: That is very curious!—You know all that!—We do not know any thing of the matter.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Oh, it is ſoon learned.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: I ſhould like to keep bees.

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: Perhaps, mama, will let us.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: But we do not know how to manage them.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: I will ſhew you, with all my heart, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Oh, thank you, thank you; how good you are!

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: And to plant flowers alſo?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Yes, ſurely.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Oh, delightful!—Roſetta, what flower is this?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: A larkſpur—Here is another, of a different colour.—They are various in colour, and ſome are double.—They are annuals.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: What do you mean by annuals?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: They laſt but one year.—the ſeed muſt be ſaved, and ſowed again. Moſt of our common flowers are annuals.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p:
Oh, but you forget
roſes, honeyſuckles, lilacs, and jaſmine?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Thoſe are called flowering ſhrubs.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: How much you know!—We know nothing of all this!

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Oh, there is nothing more eaſy, when one lives in the country.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: But you have been taught all this?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Not at all; I need only obſerve.—I do not need telling.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: And we know nothing but what we are taught.—And yet we fancy ourſelves very wiſe!—No wonder your time is employed!—What elſe do you do?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p:
I work a great deal.—I read whenever I can: I make cakes, and paſtry: I help to gather the fruit in ſeaſon, and to cull flowers and herbs for diſtilling: I
manage the poultry-yard, and overlook the dairy.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Oh, how clever you are!—I wiſh I could do ſo.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: There is nothing clever in that; I only do my duty.—You are differently ſituated, you have no need of theſe things.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: For all that, they are more uſeful.—But if we did what mama wiſhes us, that would be enough.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: To be ſure it is.—You do, I dare ſay.

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: No, truly.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: No.—Mama wiſhes us to read more; not to be conceited; to ſpend leſs time idly; to talk leſs ourſelves, and attend more to other people.—Not to be impertinent; and above all not to quarrel.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: No doubt, you obey ſuch reaſonable, and kind commands.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Yes—when we remember!—But to-day—I ſee now how fooliſhly I have behaved!—How ignorant, I fancied you were, becauſe you could not dance and ſing!—How I chattered to you without attending to what you ſaid!—Then I was very impertinent to you, and quarrelled with Harriot.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: But, dear Miſs Matilda, how I love you for owning your faults!—You will ſoon mend them.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Ah!—I fear not!

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Yes, ſince you know them ſo well!

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: You allow, then, I have faults; I love you for that: every body elſe, except Mama, my Governeſs, and Maria flatter me.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: To flatter!—Oh, how vile!

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Do they not flatter you?—

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p:
No, ſurely; I ſhould
• eſpiſe any one who did.—What! • ake us more faulty, by pretending to think us perfect?—Is it not 〈◊〉 ?—Such people muſt either wiſh us to be blameable out of ill-nature, that they may ridicule us, or mean to make ſome advantage of our faults.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: I believe you are right; I ſhall be more cautious in future.—Roſetta promiſe to tell me when I am wrong.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Ah! have you not a mother, much more capable than I am of telling you?

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Yes; but I behave better when mama ſees me.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: And why?

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Becauſe I know ſhe will love me better

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: What then does ſhe wiſh you to ſeem good, or really to be ſo?

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Oh, really to be ſo without doubt.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Then you do not anſwer her wiſhes, if you are le • good when ſhe does not ſee you, than when ſhe does.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Very true indeed!—Oh, you ſhall ſee I will be very good henceforward.—We ſhall have you with us often, I hope.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Certainly; I ſhall be happy, if Mrs. Montfort pleaſes.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Oh, I am ſure ſhe will like it.—Here comes mama.—I ſhall aſk her.—Harriot, you will like it too; ſhall you not?

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: Oh yes, indeed.

sp.speaker: Matilda,
sp.p: Mama mama!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort.
sp.p: Well!—What ſay you?

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p:
Mama, will you not
• e Miſs Roſetta to come and ſee 〈◊〉 ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort.
sp.p: Yes, certainly, 〈◊〉 often as ſhe can make it convenient to come to you.—At all yours, my dear Roſetta; if the children are taking their leſſons, they • all not diſturb themſelves; you • ill not perhaps be ſorry to be of • e party.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Thank you, ma'am, • ou are very kind indeed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort.
sp.p: I ſee, Matilda, 〈◊〉 this requeſt, that at laſt you underſtand the merit of your companion.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Oh, yes, indeed, mama!—She knows ſo much; ſhe underſtands flowers, and how to keep bees, and to make cakes, and many other things.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort.
sp.p:
Yes—and that 〈◊〉 not all.—She helps her mother
to inſtruct her ſiſters, in working reading, and writing.—Beſides the aſſiſtance ſhe gives in houſhold affairs, ſhe works excellently we at her needle.—She is fond of reading, and has greatly improved by it.—I beg your pardon, Roſetta for commending you to your face but I wiſh to give my children leſſon, who fancied this morning, becauſe you had not the ſame advantages with themſelves; you muſt be ignorant and awk ward. They now ſee you are neither; and the • begin to know how much mo •• valuable and uſeful are your employments than theirs.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Indeed, ma'am, the young ladies were not miſtaken; am very ignorant.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort.
sp.p:
You are very modeſt; which will, I hope, be another leſſon to them.—Beſide
Matilda, Miſs Roſetta is not deficient in thoſe lighter accompliſhments which you admire ſo much.—She has taught herſelf to deſign landſcapes, and to paint flowers, charmingly well, and ſhe alſo ſings very agreeably.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: What! Roſetta, can you ſing?

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: But—very little indeed.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: You did not ſay ſo this morning.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: You only aſked me, if I had learn'd; and, I ſaid, I had not; which is true.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Mama, I am quite convinced of what you have ſo often told me, that by chatting ſo much, attending ſo much to myſelf, and ſo little to other people, I loſe a great deal of pleaſure and inſtruction.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort.
sp.p:
Yes.—If you
had not choſen to diſplay what you fancied your ſuperiority, in dancing and ſinging, to Miſs Roſetta, you would earlier have learnt her merit, and the power ſhe has of teaching you many uſeful and agreeable things.—You would have ſaved yourſelf the pain of being impertinent to her, and me the mortification of ſeeing you rude, ſaucy, and conceited.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Mama—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort.
sp.p: Indeed, you were all theſe!—But, hence forward, Matilda, I hope you will reflect, that the light frivolous accompliſhments you have boaſted of ſo much, are in reality of no eſſential import, ſince they neither make us more wiſe, more humble, or more pleaſing in our behaviour.

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p:
But mama, do you not
then wiſh us to learn ſinging and dancing?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort.
sp.p: Certainly.—It is a duty incumbent on you to learn them, becauſe I wiſh it, and becauſe they are ornamental parts of education, ſuited to the place you are to • ill in life.—But I would not have you fancy they make you at all ſuperior to thoſe whoſe ſituation excludes them from ſuch information.—You will do very wrong not to learn them, but you have no merit in poſſeſſing them, as every other perſon would do the ſame, if they had the ſame opportunity.—And I would have you always conſider, that one precept which teaches you to improve your behaviour, or regulate your temper, is of more value than the fineſt ſinging, or moſt graceful dancing.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: I am ſure you are right, mama.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort.
sp.p: Even ſuperior acquirements ought not to render you proud or conceited.—If you read more, or write better, than other children of your age; if you know better how to behave, or have better qualities, you ought to reflect that all have not equal advantages with yourſelf.—Every child has not a father, who can or will be at the expence of having her well inſtructed.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Ah, mama, nor has every child a mother who takes ſuch pains in teaching her!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort.
sp.p:
That is true,—Learn then to make allowances for differences of natural capacity, which we have no merit in poſſeſſing, as we did not give it to ourſelves; and for difference of education,
which depends on thoſe about us,—When theſe allowances are made, we ſhall ſeldom, if ever, find any thing to ridicule or deſpiſe; pity, and a wiſh to amend, will be our only ſentiments.—And when we conſider how many opportunities we have ourſelves loſt, how much more we might have learned, than we have learned, we may eaſily allow for thoſe who have even loſt more time than ourſelves.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Ah, mama, I feel how much you are in the right; and I promiſe you henceforth to be more attentive, and leſs preſuming.

sp.speaker: Harriot.
sp.p: And I alſo, indeed, mama.

sp.speaker: Roſetta.
sp.p: Ah, ma'ma, let me too thank you for theſe valuable inſtructions; which, I hope, will be alſo profitable to me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Montfort.
sp.p:
You are a very
good girl, my dear Roſetta.—I hope you will come hither often, and that the connection will be mutually uſeful.—Let us go in; it is tea-time.

figure.head: The Distrest Family. Vilmats distreſs relieved by Mr. and Miſs Barclay

q.l: Such fate to ſuffering worth is given,
Who long with wants and woes has ſtriven;
