By cruel fraud and cunning driven
To miſery's brink.
'Till wrench'd of every ſtay, ſave Heav'n,
He ruin'd ſunk.

div.head: THE DISTREST FAMILY.
div.stage: SCENE before a Cottage, with a ſmall railed Garden, a diſtant view of a Village, the Church, &c.—
Wilmot comes out of the Cottage.

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p:
THE Sun is ariſen; the miſts are partly diſpelled.—How pure is the air!—For a moment let me try to forget my cares, and enjoy theſe refreſhing odours.—(He pauſes.)—Oh, how vain the attempt!—Theſe ſcenes, the moment of day-break, once ſo delicious to my heart, to
which it uſed to expand with ſo much rapture, have loſt their power!—Oh, my God, it was here I uſed to offer to thee my morning ſacrifice of praiſe and prayer. It was here, ſoftened into univerſal benevolence, I uſed to pray for all men.—I no longer feel thoſe delightful emotions.—A weight of grief hangs upon my heart. The ardour of my devotion is departed. My wiſhes are contracted to a point.—I have loſt my hopes on earth; and, I fear, I am alſo loſing my truſt in God.—Oh, my heavenly father, deign to hear me!—Suffer me not to deſpair of thy mercies, or to murmur at thy will!—Teach me to ſupport my anguiſh, if not with the fortitude of a man, with the reſignation of a chriſtian!(He leans againſt a tree, with his face on his arms, in thought.)
Rachel enters from the cottage; as ſhe ſhuts the door, ſhe looks back▪ and ſays.—Be quiet, George—don't make a noiſe, I ſhall be back in a minute.

sp.speaker: Rachel,
sp.p: Father, my dear father, why are you ſo ſad?

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: My child!

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Indeed, father, my mother is better.—She ſleeps.

sp.speaker: Wilmot,
sp.p:
She will ſoon ſleep in death!—Muſt I ſee her die!—Without friends, without the means of procuring her proper aſſiſtence, I ſee her languiſhing under a diſeaſe which might be cured, could I but obtain proper nouriſhment for her.—Why do I heſitate!—Driven from men, as if I did not belong to their ſpecies, the bands between me and ſociety are broken;
wherefore then ſhould I not fall, like a beaſt of prey, on thoſe barbarous wretches who leave us to periſh.

sp.speaker: Rachel,
sp.p: Father you did not bid me pray to-day, but I have prayed.—Why do you not teach me to be good, as you uſed to do?

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: Oh, my child!—My God! thou haſt made this innocent my preſerver.—Are the bands between me and ſociety broken!—Oh no! my children are ties which I dare not break.—Thou haſt truſted them to me!—Dare I corrupt thy work, and lead thoſe to wickedneſs and miſery whom thou haſt created to be good and happy?

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: What do you mean, father?—Why do you cry—why do you ſpeak ſo haſtily—are you angry with me?

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: No, my child, no I—Happy innocent!—thou knoweſt not the force of the paſſions!—thou readeſt not the anguiſh of a heart, fluctuating between good and evil.—Go my child to thy mother; ſhe may want thee.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: I will, father.—(As ſhe goes out, ſhe meets Mr. Johnſon.—She curtſies, but he takes no notice.)

sp.speaker: Rachel,
sp.p: How croſs he looks!—I hope he won't ſcold my father!—What can make people ſo croſs, I wonder!

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: Good-day to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Johnſon.
sp.p: Servant, George.—What art doing here; why doſt not get to work man?

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p:
Sir, I am going to work; but my wife has been ill all night.—I fear for her life.—I
know not how to leave her, leſt I ſhould ſee her no more.

sp.speaker: Johnſon.
sp.p: Well, well, man, if thee doſt not work, thy wife cannot eat, nor thy children neither: that's all I know.

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, I would I were able to work inceſſantly, for their ſakes; would that I could live without reſt, that I might earn more for their ſupport.

sp.speaker: Johnſon.
sp.p: Well, then, why doſt ſtand idle?

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, it is not idleneſs, my ſtrength, and my ſpirits fail me, but never my wiſh to labour.

sp.speaker: Johnſon.
sp.p: How thou talk'ſt of thy ſtrength, and thy ſtrength; haſt not as much ſtrength as another?

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: At leaſt, Sir, what have I employ willingly.

sp.speaker: Johnſon.
sp.p:
Don't know that.—
Thou doſt not as much work in a day and a half, as ſome of my men do in a day.—George, George, I am afraid thee art lazy and then thy wife, ſhe is ſick.—She ſays ſo however; ſhe can't do this, and ſhe can't do that; her betters can do it.—God knows how you contrive to live!

sp.speaker: Wilmot,
sp.p: Yes, Sir!—God does know!—He ſees our hearts; he knows whether or not I wiſh to work; whether or not my poor Agnes is really ſick.—Ah, Heaven, I can bear any thing for myſelf, but I have not yet learnt to bear reproach on her!

sp.speaker: Johnſon.
sp.p: Well, well, George, thou ſeem'ſt not to be cut out for a working man, thou look'ſt and talk'ſt like a gentleman, ſo may be thou know'ſt how to live like one, I'am ſure I've no objection.

sp.speaker: Wilmot,
sp.p: What cruel inſults!—Down proud and rebellious ſpirit.—I will be humble! (To Johnſon.)—Ah, Sir, gentlemen do not live as I live; gentlemen do not ſee thoſe they love dying before their eyes, without the power of giving them aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Johnſon.
sp.p: I'll tell thee what, George; if thou can'ſt afford to ſtand chattering here all day, I cannot.—So fare thee well; ſince thou haſt not a mind to work, I muſt find ſomebody who has.

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: Good heavens, Sir!—I am going to work inſtantly; do not, I conjure you, do not think of employing another.

sp.speaker: Johnſon.
sp.p: Well, well, I ſhall ſee about it.

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: But, Sir, hear me, I pray you: promiſe me that you will not employ another.—Conſider my poor wife and children.

sp.speaker: Johnſon.
sp.p: 'Tis for thee to conſider them, and work the harder.

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you need not fear me; you ſhall have no reaſon to complain.

sp.speaker: Johnſon.
sp.p: We ſhall ſee that.—Go to work.—The men have been in the fields this half hour. Make haſte, and we ſhall ſee.

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: I ſhall, Sir. (Johnſon goes out.)

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p:
Oh God!—Oh God!—hear my groans! Pity me, and teach this cruel man to pity me!—Make me forget I ever was, what I am not now!—Oh that I could acquire at once the ſtrength and humility of the hardy peaſant!—My blood riſes, my heart ſwells; hardly could I reſtrain myſelf from anſwering this tyrant as he deſerved.—Let me ſee my Agnes once
more, and then haſten to obey this imperious maſter.
sp.stage: (He goes into the cottage, then comes cut again, croſſes the ſtage, and goes out. Rachel and George follow him.)

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Good-bye, father good-bye.—Come, George, let us go and get ſome ſticks, to boil the potatoes.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: But mother will want you.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: No, ſhe ſays ſhe is better.—She will not eat any breakfaſt, however.—She does not like bread.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I like it—but I like it beſt with an apple.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Oh, but apples are ſcarce.—Our tree had but a few, and thoſe muſt be ſaved for mother: ſhe can eat a bit now and then.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p:
I am ſure, then, I don't
want them.—I had rather ſhe had them.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: I am ſure I wiſh I could live without eating, that mama might have better things.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Mama! You muſt not ſay that.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Oh, I had forgot; I muſt never ſay, mama, ſince Nancy Johnſon laughed at me, and her mother ſcolded me for ſaying ſo.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I hate Nancy Johnſon; ſhe's ſo proud and ill-temper'd.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Oh, but you muſt not • ate any body.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Well, I will hate Mrs. Johnſon, however, becauſe ſhe's ſo croſs to mother.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: You will hate her.—I cannot help laughing at that.
sp.stage: (While they are laughing, Mr. Barclay and Eleonora come in.)

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p: Dear papa, what pretty children.—What's your name my dear?

sp.speaker: Rachel,
sp.p: Rachel Wilmot, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p: A very pretty name, and I dare ſay you are a very good girl.—Is that your brother?

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p: And what were you laughing at ſo heartily, my dear!

sp.speaker: Rachel,
sp.p: At—a • George, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p: What did he ſay • then?

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p:
Ma'am, he ſays he w ••
hate Mrs. Johnſon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay,
sp.p: A very kind determination.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Oh dear, ma'am, bu • pray don't tell her.—Perhaps you know her.—Pray don't be angry, • e is but a child.

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p: Be eaſy, I don't know her; and if I did, I ſhould not tell her.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Oh, I'm glad of that.—Perhaps it might ruin my father.

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: How ſo, child?

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Sir my father works for Mr. Johnſon; and, perhaps, they might be affronted.

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: Very likely.—We will not tell them. Be good children—mind your book.—Let me ſee you at church, and here is ſix-pence for you.

sp.speaker: Rachel,
sp.p: (joyfully.) Oh dear Sir, will you be ſo kind then as to let me work for you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: Work, my child!—What work can'ſt thou do?—Why, do'ſt think I will give the • work?

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Will you not, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: I have none for you, child.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Then, Sir, what am I to do with this money?

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: Keep it, my child.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Sir, my father ſays, I muſt not take money till I can work for it.—He forbids me to beg.

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: Charming little creature!

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p: How amiable!—But, my dear, you did not beg; my papa gave it to you.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: But I don't think my father would like me to have it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: Her integrity i • charming!—Look then, my child, I want thoſe flowers which grow yonder.—I will give you ſix-pence to gather them for me.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Oh, yes, Sir, yes.

stage.hi:
(She runs and gathers the flowers.
Mr. Barclay gives her the ſix-pence, and the flowers to Eleonora.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: Keep them, my Eleonora, and if ever you ſhould be tempted to forget my precepts, let them remind you how well this little cottager kept thoſe of her father.

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p: I can never forget it.—Adieu, Rachel. I ſhall ſee you again ſome time or other.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Good-bye, ma'am.—Thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p:
O, George, ſee!—I have got ſix-pence!—I ſhall go directly to the village, and buy mother ſome biſcuits, ſuch as ſhe likes, and ſome coffee: I can have both for ſix-pence.—Go in—don't tell her where I am gone.—If ſhe wants
any thing, Dame Green will come if you call her.—Don't make a racket.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: No, no.—Good-bye.
sp.stage: (Rachel goes out. George goes into the cottage.)

div.head: The Diſtreſt Family.
PART II.
div.stage: SCENE, the Inſide of the Cottage.
Agnes, Rachel, George.—A ſmall table ſtands by Agnes, with coffee, and buiſcuits.—A little inner room is ſeen, with a bed.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: BUT, mother, you don't eat the buiſcuits.

sp.speaker: Agnes.
sp.p: Yes, my dear, I have eaten one; take one yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: No, thank ye, mother.

sp.speaker: Agnes.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: I am not hungry.

sp.speaker: Agnes.
sp.p: My child, there are more than I can eat; you may take one ſafely.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: But, mother, they will not be ſpoiled by to-morrow, and they are better for you than bread.—I like bread very much.

sp.speaker: Agnes.
sp.p: My dear Rachel! (embraces her with tears.)—My God, I thank the for the bleſſing of ſuch affectionate children: they comfort me in all my diſtreſſes! Rachel ſee if your father is coming.

sp.speaker: Rachel,
sp.p: No, mother, it is twelve o'clock too; how very hot it is!

sp.speaker: Agnes.
sp.p: Alas, how my poor Wilmot will be fatigued.—He exhauſts his ſtrength in working for us.—I dare not wiſh to die, for I know how much my death would afflict him!—And my poor children, they yet need a mother's care!

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Mother, my dear mother, why do you cry; my father will ſoon be here.

sp.speaker: George,
sp.p: Don't cry, mother, my father is coming.

sp.speaker: Agnes.
sp.p: Do not tell him I have been crying.—I am better now; how near is he?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Mother, he is juſt getting over the ſtile; he looks up to the ſky; he wipes his face.—Ah, how hot he is; I will run out to him.

sp.speaker: Agnes.
sp.p: Ah, how he muſt be fatigued!—In this burning Sun—he that was ſo delicately bred!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Here he is, mother—here he is!

sp.speaker: Agnes.
sp.p: My dear Wilmot!—How tired you are.

sp.speaker: Rachel,
sp.p: Sit down here father; let me take your hat.

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: The Sun is ſo hot!—My dear Agnes, how are you?

sp.speaker: Agnes.
sp.p: Better, thank you!—Rachel has procured me ſome coffee; it has done me good.—Take a cup of it, it will refreſh you.

sp.speaker: Wilmot,
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Agnes.
sp.p: What is the matter?—You look pale. Oh, Wilmot, ſpeak to me, for God's ſake.—You are ill?—Ah, he is dying. He has killed himſelf for me!

stage.hi: (Wilmot fainting, leans back. Agnes runs for water, and ſprinkles him. Rachel and George ſcream. Rachel r • us to the door.)

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Help, help!—Oh, my father is dying. Mother, mother, don't you die too.

sp.speaker: George,
sp.p: Oh, mother mother!
sp.stage: (A knocking at the door.—After a while, it is repeated.)

sp.speaker: Agnes.
sp.p: Wilmot, Wilmot ſpeak to me, ſpeak to me.

stage.hi: (The knocking is heard again. Rachel opens the door. Mr. Barclay and Eleonora come in. Agnes ſtill hangs over Wilmot, in the greateſt agony.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: What is the matter, good people—What occaſioned the ſcreams I heard?

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, my father is dead, and my mother is dying.—George, George, let us die too!

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p: My dear, don't be frighten'd—he is not dead, he will ſoon recover. (To Agnes.) Pray don't be ſo terrified.
sp.stage: (Agnes looks only at Wilmot. Eleonora takes out her ſalts; applies them to Wilmot. Mr. Barclay ſupports him)

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: My good woman, recover yourſelf; he is only faint.

sp.speaker: Agnes.
sp.p:
Oh no, he is dead.—
I have killed him. Wilmot, I ſhall not out-live you.
sp.stage: (Wilmot begins to recover; half raiſes his head, and looks at Agnes.—In a moment he ſpeaks.)

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: My wife!

sp.speaker: Agnes.
sp.p: I am here—I am at your ſide.—I will not leave you even in death.

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: My deareſt Agnes, I am better; do not terrify yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p: Indeed there is no need—he will be well preſently.

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: Ah, Madam, I beg your pardon.—I fear I have been troubleſome to you?

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p: By no means; your wife and children have been ſadly alarmed.—Pray prevail on your wife to take ſome care of herſelf.

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: Agnes, I entreat you to ſit down.

sp.speaker: Eleonora,
sp.p: Take a little water, will you?—Rachel, ſhew me where it is, I will fetch ſome.
sp.stage: (She fetches water, and obliges Agnes to drink of it, who is relieved by a violent fit of crying.)

sp.speaker: Agnes.
sp.p: Thank you ma'am; you are extremely good.

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: Have you been ill long, my friend?

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: No, Sir, I was very well this morning.

sp.speaker: Agnes.
sp.p: Ah, my dear Wilmot you have over-worked yourſelf.—This burning Sun—Your cares, your anxiety, have overcome you!—Why would you do ſo?

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: My dear Agnes, if you knew the terrors I have ſuffered!

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: The terrors!

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, of being deprived of my work. My maſter threatened me this morning with diſmiſſion; he accuſes me of lazineſs.

sp.speaker: Agnes.
sp.p: Oh, what you!—You who have worked ſo eagerly, ſo conſtantly?

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p:
Alas, yes!—Unable before to procure for you, my dear Agnes, the ſupport your diſeaſe required, could I bear the idea of loſing the common neceſſaries for you, and for my children?—Nor was this all, the cruel man added the moſt bitter and unprovoked reflections on me, and thoſe I love beſt.—I left you, Agnes, this morning half heart broken, and ſcarcely able to reſolve on longer enduring a miſerable exiſtence, except for thoſe dear ſakes, whoſe rememberance
urged me on beyond my ſtrength!

sp.speaker: Agnes.
sp.p: Ah, Wilmot, to us then you owe your illneſs, even perhaps your death; to us who would have died to ſave you!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Father, let me help you to work to-morrow; perhaps Mr • Johnſon won't ſcold then.

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: Alas, my child!

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: Pray tell me, who is this oppreſſive man, this Johnſon, of whom you ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: Sir, he is the farmer who employs me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: Where does he live?

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: In a farm called Oatley, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p:
I thought ſo!—It is my farm, and he is now urging me for a new leaſe, on terms very favourable to himſelf.—I am glad
to learn how I ought to deal with him.

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: I ſhould be ſorry, Sir, to prejudice you againſt him; he is honeſt, and a good farmer.

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: You do yourſelf honour, by thus repaying his unkindneſs; but he muſt not expect me to favour a man capable of ſuch conduct.

sp.speaker: Agnes.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, ma'am, for not aſking you to ſit down.—We are exceedingly indebted to you for the trouble you have taken.

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt.—I would not be impertinent; but—can we be of ſervice to you?

sp.speaker: Wilmot,
sp.p: Vain prejudice, which has ſo long taught me to conceal my diſtreſſes, begone!—Unable longer to labour, I muſt apply to the compaſſion of others, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: Speak freely, my good friend.—Can I aſſiſt you?

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, the dear woman you ſee has been ill a long time; ſhe is better, but her weak ſtate requires nouriſhment, which I cannot procure for her.

sp.speaker: Agnes.
sp.p: My dear Wilmot, think more of yourſelf, and leſs of me.—It is he, Sir, who requires your aſſiſtance.—I have already taken refreſhment, which your kindneſs this morning enabled my child to procure.

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: What! my little flower-gatherer!—Amiable child!

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p: My good friend, your huſband ſeems much recovered; you are yourſelf indiſpoſed, be prevailed on to lie down; in the mean time my father will learn how he can be of uſe to you.

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: Do, my dear Agnes; I am quite well.

sp.speaker: Agnes.
sp.p: Since you requeſt it, I will obey you.

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p: Let me help you?

sp.speaker: Agnes.
sp.p: Oh no!—dear young lady, I cannot bear you ſhould wait on me.

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p: Why not?—It is a pleaſure to me.

sp.speaker: Agnes.
sp.p: But it is giving you ſo much trouble.

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p: Not at all.—I dare ſay, if I were ſick, and you were well, you would wait on me?

sp.speaker: Agnes.
sp.p: Moſt ſurely.—It would be fit I ſhould be your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p: To be ſure, it is always fit thoſe who are in health ſhould wait on thoſe who are ſick.

sp.speaker: Agnes.
sp.p: What ſweetneſs!
sp.stage: (She goes out, leaning on Eleonora, followed by Rachel; in a minute Eleonora returns.)

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.stage: (in a low voice, to her father.)
sp.p: Sir, theſe poor people have great need of refreſhment, let me fetch it from home, I will return preſently.

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: Do ſo, but do not run, it is too hot.

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p: I will not.
sp.stage: (Mr. Barclay, Wilmot, George at a diſtance.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: My child will ſoon return; ſhe is gone for refreſhment.

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, how can I thank you for your goodneſs!

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: My good friend, why would you not apply to me before?

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p:
Sir, while I was able by the work of my hands, to procure for my wife and children the means of life, I had no right to
encroach upon the goodneſs of others, or on that relief which poorer wtetches had a better right to.—But when my ſtrength failed me; when I ſaw myſelf on the point of being deprived of work, and my children of bread, it became time to aſk, and God has been pleaſed that I ſhould not aſk in vain.

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: I admire your ſentiments, and—

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Father, my mother is inclined to ſleep, but every time her eyes cloſe ſhe ſtarts and fancies ſhe • ees you fainting again.—If you go to her, perhaps, ſhe will be eaſy.

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p:
Go, my friend, no apologies; I will chat awhile
with Rachel; I ſhall tell you a charming ſtory of her.
sp.stage: (Wilmot goes in. Rachel ſtands by Mr. Barclay.)

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Will my mother get well ſoon, Sir, do you think?

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: I hope ſo my dear: has ſhe been ill long?

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Oh yes, Sir, a great while: all the winter ſhe had a cough, but it is gone; but ſhe is ſo weak, and then ſhe cannot eat bread and potatoes, as we do.—I bought her ſome coffee to-day, with the money I had from you, Sir.—She took ſome.—I was ſo pleaſed!—But my father frighted us ſadly!

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee him ſo before?

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: No, Sir; he is often tired very much indeed, but not ſo bad.—To be ſure, he has not been uſed to ſuch hard work.

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: What work then has he been uſed to, my child?

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Why, Sir, it is a great while ago, before George can remember, we lived in a nice houſe, and had ſervants, and I had white frocks, and fine people uſed to come and ſee us!—But now the fine people don't come, Sir; why don't they?

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: Happy innocent▪—Thou knoweſt not how eagerly the great fly from the unfortunate!

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: My dear!—What, have you carried that baſket thro' the heat?

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p:
No, Sir, I thought you would not be pleaſed, ſo I made John bring it to the gate, but I would not let him come in
for theſe people ſeem to have ſo much feeling, I could not bear to bring an unneceſſa •••• witneſs of their diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay,
sp.p: (embracing her.) My dear girl!

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p: Rachel, ſee if your mother is aſleep.
sp.stage: (Rachel goes into the inner room. Wilmot comes out.)

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: My poor Agnes can get no r • ſt.

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p: I will go to her.—I have brought ſome drops, which will compoſe her ſpirits.

stage.hi:
(Sh •
•• kes cut of the baſket a bottle of wine, two glaſſes, ſlices of cold ham, and bread and cakes.)

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p: Papa, will you eat ſomething?—Perhaps Mr. Wilmot will take a glaſs of wine.

sp.speaker: Wilmot,
sp.p:
(aſide.) Charming delicacy!
—How I feel that kindneſs!
sp.stage: (Eleonora goes into the inner room. Mr. Barclay and Wilmot ſit at the table. Rachel and George creep towards them. Mr. Barclay gives them cakes. They all eat.)

sp.speaker: Wilmot,
sp.p: Angelic charity!—Not contented with furniſhing the means of health, ſhe adminiſters them herſelf, waiting with humility and ſweetneſs on the poor and wretched

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
Wilmot.
sp.p: No; you cannot.—Warm and feeling, your hearts make the diſtreſſes of others your own.

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: That is no matter of wonder.

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: Oh! not to you.—Goodneſs is to you too common to be wonderful.—But to me, to me who have been rejected by the world, caſt off by my relations, ſuch kindneſs is ſcarcely credible!

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: Your lot ſeems to have been an hard one, but let it not make you think ill of all mankind.—There ſeems to be ſomething uncommon in your ſtory and if the recital be not painful—

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: The recital, Sir, I thank God, will not be painful, for I have no guilt of my own to relate.

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: I dare engage it.

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p:
Perhaps, of ſome imprudence, you will not ſo eaſily acquit me.—I was born to a good eſtate; juſt after I came of age,
my father died; ſoon after, I married that dear woman you have ſeen.—She was of good family, but had no fortune; mine was ſufficient for us both, but fond as I was of my Agnes, deſiring to procure for her every indulgence, I lived to the extent of my income, and far beyond her wiſhes: for five years we lived happily, when a diſtant relation of the perſon from whom my father had bought the eſtate, pretending a fault in the title, laid claim to it; the cauſe was tried, and by an artifice my chief witneſs kept out of court. I loſt my cauſe, and was left deſtitute; my relations excuſing themſelves on account of my marrying, as they called it, imprudently, and my living expenſively, refuſed me any aſſiſtance, and with the reſt of my friends, turned their back • upon me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: What cruel conduct!

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: One friend alone was left, who received us into his houſe, and would have procured a re-hearing of our cauſe, but he died, and we were ſent forth to wander through the world. I hired this cottage, where, by the labour of my hands, I have ſupported my wife, that dear conſoling angel, who has never once reproached me for the miſery I have brought upon her, and our children; till her ſickneſs drove me almoſt to diſtraction and deſpair, from which Heaven ſent you this day to relieve me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: Make yourſelf eaſy, I hope all will be well; our firſt care muſt be to reſtore your wife.—Is the perſon yet alive who was to have witneſſed in your cauſe?

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: He is.

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: Very well, My dear Wilmot hear me, I am tolerably rich, I have only one child, I will ſupport you in this cauſe if, on enquiry, I find you are likely to ſucceed, and I will only a •• in return your promiſe to repay me when you regain your eſtate.

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: Sir—ſuch amazing kindneſs to a ſtranger!

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: No, Wilmot, not to a ſtranger. I knew your father well; he was my ſenior at college. I have often heard of this cauſe as a moſt iniquitous tranſaction, and I have no doubt of your ſucceſs, ſo that all the favour I do you is to advance you a little money; no mighty obligation!

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: Oh yes!—My obligations to you are mighty, are not to be repaid!—Beſt of men!

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: Pſha! there are thouſands better.

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: Such amazing generoſity!

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: There is really no generoſity in the matter.—I am ſure of my ſecurity.

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: What, Sir!—The word of a perſon you do not know▪

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: No, Wilmot, not of a perſon I do not know.—I have ſeen enough of you to convince me you are honeſt and grateful; what better ſecurity ſhould I deſire?

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: I am overpowered!—My children, bleſs your benefactor!

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, will you make my father and mother well and happy?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: And will you give my mother ſomething better to eat than potatoes?

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: Oh yes, my children, he will ſave us all.—Thank him then; learn to love and ſerve him; keep about you—never forget the form of this cottage; and if, as I hope, we live to inhabit a better place, remember always who reſcued us from poverty!

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: No more, no more; if you will think yourſelf obliged to me, in return do me the favour not to thank me.

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p: Mr. Wilmot, your wife is aſleep; ſhe will be well, I da • e ſay—and you, how are you?

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: Oh, well, quite well!—The bleſſing of Heaven accompanies you; all muſt be well where you are.

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p:
Wilmot think of what I have ſaid to yo • . In the evening I will ſend my carriage
to bring you all to my houſe, where you ſhall remain, either till your cauſe is gained, or, if that cannot be, till I can place you in ſome way of life better ſuited to your birth. (To Eleonora.) My dear, Mr. Wilmot is entitled to a very large fortune, which I hope to procure for him.

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p: I am very glad of i • , but fortune cannot add to my reſpect for people ſo worthy.

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: Angelic creature!—How can I ever want—

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: You forget my injunctions!—I ſhall ſend for you—be ready.—In the mean time; take care of yourſelves.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: What, father, ſhall we ride in a coach?

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p:
Yes, my dear, often, every day, if you continue good: and, what is better, you ſhall have
a great many charming little books.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Oh, how glad I ſhall be.

sp.speaker: Mr. Barclay.
sp.p: Wilmot, Farewel!

sp.speaker: Eleonora.
sp.p: Farewel, Mr. Wilmot.—Good-bye, Rachel; we ſhall except you.

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p: Every bleſſing attend you!

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Thank you, thank you.
sp.stage: (She kiſſes Eleonora's hand, who embraces her.—Wilmot attends Mr. Barclay to the door, and returns.)

sp.speaker: Wilmot.
sp.p:
Oh my God!—How can I ever thank thee, for ſuch amazing goodneſs!—Heart broken, wearied, on the point of renouncing my dependance on thee; of • eting thy laws at defiance; that moment haſt thou choſen to relieve and bleſs me!—Aweful and ſtriking
leſſon!—Shall I ever again deſpair, when I know that the next hour to that of our greateſt miſery may bring with it comfort and happineſs!—I hear my Agnes coming; let me meet and explain to her theſe happy events!

div.p: The limits of the Drama not allowing of the events being finiſhed, it may perhaps be ſatisfactory to the reader to hear, that Mrs. Wilmot recovered; and that Wilmot, gaining his cauſe, by Mr. Barclay's means, was reſtored to affluence, and the two families formed a friendſhip, which laſted during their lives.

Lady Aubrey,

div.head: THE VILLAGE WEDDING.
div.stage: SCENE, a Lawn before a Cottage.

(Under the ſhade of ſome trees a table is ſpread, with fruits, milk, and cyder. Robert, and ſome old peaſants, ſit at this table. Philip, Lucetta, and ſome young peaſants, are dancing on the lawn. Lucetta is dreſſed in white, with flowers, as a bride, Philip as a bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: AYE, marry neighbour, it does my heart good to ſee them,—Look ye there, I'll warrant ye as light as the beſt!

sp.speaker: Old Peaſant.
sp.p: Truly, neighbour Robert, Lucetta is a pretty girl; yes, yes, you may well be proud of her. She is not only handſome, but good.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Ah, neighbour!—She is the joy of my old heart!—Had her mother lived to ſee this day!

sp.speaker: Old Peaſant.
sp.p: Come cheerly, neighbour, don't let's diſturb ourſelves with ſad thoughts, we met to be merry. (Lucetta ſeeing her father look ſad, 〈◊〉 out of the dance.)

sp.speaker: Lucetta.
sp.p: Ah, father!—What's the matter?—You are not ill?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: No, no, my child, I am very well, and very happy.

sp.speaker: Lucetta.
sp.p: Well, then!—why look ſad!—on my wedding-day too!—Truly, I will not excuſe it!

sp.speaker: Robert,
sp.p: (taking her in his arms.) My child, I do not weep for ſorrow, but for joy, thou art ſo good, and ſo happy.

sp.speaker: Lucetta.
sp.p: Ah, my dear father, I owe both to you!—but not a ſingle tear muſt you ſhed to-day.—Ah, ha, here comes Philip; he thinks ſomething is the matter.
sp.stage: (She runs to Philip, gives him her hand, he leads her back to the dance.)

sp.speaker: Old Peaſant.
sp.p: Aye, aye, they are happy enough!—Well, they be a ſweet couple.

sp.speaker: Old Woman.
sp.p:
As to Lucetta, I muſt ſay, I don't know her equal, nor ever did, except my poor daughter, that's gone.—Marry neighbour Robert, I have reaſon to love your girl; how kind ſhe was to me, when my poor daughter lay ſick.—Don't grieve ſo,
neighbour Martha, ſhe would ſay, pray don't; I'll do all I can to fill your daughter's place.—Ah, and ſo ſhe has; ſhe tended me when I was ſick; ſhe works for me, now my eye-fight fails! Ah, marry, I love her as if ſhe was my own!

sp.speaker: Second Old Woman.
sp.p: Then ſhe is ſo kind to the children; my little grand-daughters run when they ſee her coming—here's Lucetta, they ſay, here's Lucetta; truly, 'tis a holiday to ſee her?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Ah, it does my heart good, to hear her praiſes!—What a bleſſed thing it is to have every body's good word!

sp.speaker: Old Peaſant.
sp.p: Aye, Robert, that's the honeſt man's reward, to be well thought of himſelf, and leave a good name to his children!

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p:
True, neighbour, true; but look, here's gentlefolk Marry,
'tis our young 'Squire, and his bride.

sp.speaker: Old Woman.
sp.p: Yes, and that is my Lady's father, and her ſiſter.—Mercy! how handſome they be!

div.stage: Enter 'Squire and Lady Aubrey, Colonel and Miſs Neſbit.

sp.speaker: Lady Aubrey.
sp.p: What a charming ſcene!—How happy theſe good people ſeem!

sp.speaker: Colonel Neſbit.
sp.p: This appears to be a wedding.

sp.speaker: Miſs Neſbit.
sp.p: Ah, that is the bride!—What a pretty creature, and how neat.

sp.speaker: 'Squire Aubrey.
sp.p: That young man is the bridegroom, I fancy; how happy he looks!

sp.speaker: Colonel Neſbit.
sp.p: Ah!—I ſee the bride's father!

sp.speaker: Lady Aubrey.
sp.p: Where, Sir?

sp.speaker: Colonel Neſbit.
sp.p: The old peaſant, ſeated under the ſhade of thoſe trees, and ſurrounded by his neighbours.—I know him by the joy, the happineſs of his looks!—yes, I am well acquainted with the ſweet tranſports of beholding; daughter happily married.

sp.speaker: Lady Aubrey,
sp.p: (kiſſing his hand.) Ah, my dear father, your, heart has led you to him.
sp.stage: (They advance; the old people riſe up.)

sp.speaker: 'Squire Aubrey.
sp.p: Keep your ſeats, my good friends.—We are willing to ſhare with you, but not to interrupt this happy ſcene.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Won't your Honour and my good Lady, pleaſe to ſit down?

sp.speaker: 'Squire Aubrey.
sp.p: No, thank you, my old friend, we will ſtand nearer the dancers; I love to ſee them.

sp.speaker: Lady Aubrey.
sp.p: We ſhall go away, if we interrupt you good people; pray take your ſeats again.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Thank your good Ladyſhip.
sp.stage: ('Squire Aubrey, Lady Aubrey, and Miſs Neſbit, walk towards the dancers.)

sp.speaker: Colonel Neſbit.
sp.p: My honeſt friends, with your leave, I ſhall ſit with you.—We will leave the young folks to themſelves; we old ones can but look on now, though ſome years ago we could have danced with the beſt of them.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Your Honour is all goodneſs.
sp.stage: (He gives a chair. Col. Neſbit ſits down, the Peaſants ſeem to heſitate.)

sp.speaker: Colonel Neſbit.
sp.p: Come, come, ſit down all of you; I inſiſt upon it.
sp.stage: (They ſit, Robert and the Colonel a little apart from the reſt.)

sp.speaker: Colonel Neſbit.
sp.p: So, my good friend, this is a wedding, is it?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Yes, your Honour; and I pray God it may prove a happy one.

sp.speaker: Colonel Neſbit.
sp.p: I don't doubt it.—That is the bride, I ſuppoſe; a pretty girl, truly.—I muſt drink to her health.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Sir, you do her honour.

sp.speaker: Colonel Neſbit.
sp.p: I need not to be told ſhe is your daughter. I read in your face how much you are concerned in this affair.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, 'tis an affair of conſequence, indeed!—The marrying an only and dear child, is no light matter.

sp.speaker: Colonel Neſbit.
sp.p: Moſt ſurely not; and, I dare ſay, you have taken care to marry her well.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p:
Yes, your Honour, well; I hope well. Philip is a
worthy, good young man.—He has been brought up in this village; I have known him ever ſince he was half the height of my ſtick, as I may ſay.—A good tempered lad.—"Neighbour, ſhall I do this for you; ſhall I do that.—Neighbour, I am going to market; can I do any thing for you?" All that makes one love a lad.

sp.speaker: Colonel Neſbit.
sp.p: No doubt.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: At laſt, Sir, I began to find out he liked my daughter.—That made me think a little.—Lucetta, they ſay, is pretty.—I know ſhe is good: and farmer Thomas, who is main rich, had made her an offer, but the girl did not like him.—Marry, I can't ſay he is one of the beſt.—But I tire your Honour.

sp.speaker: Colonel Neſbit.
sp.p: Not at all, my friend, not at all, I take pleaſu •• in hearing you.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Your Honour is very kind.—To be ſure, Philip is poor; and I cannot give my girl much: 'tis hard, your Honour, to fear one ſhall live to ſee one's children want!—But then, I bethought me that Philip is an induſtrious lad; and Lucetta knows how to manage very prettily.—"Father, (ſaid Philip) if you give me Lucetta, don't fear while I have ſtrength but we ſhall do very well.—I'll work for her while I can, and when I can work no longer, I hope God will take care of us." What could I ſay, your Honour? I could not refuſe him, and ſo this morning they were married.

sp.speaker: Colonel Neſbit.
sp.p: You have done very right, my friend, and this muſt be a happy day to you.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p:
Ah, Sir, it is a happy day!—But yet not without its
cares.—I cannot think of the future without ſome fear!—But I rely on Providence, and hope it will ſupport a virtuous young couple, who will not ſpend their days in idleneſs.

sp.speaker: Colonel Neſbit.
sp.p:
Good old man!—you need fear nothing.—Hear me, my friend!—I am a father myſelf; I have lately experienced what it is to marry away a daughter, dearer, far dearer than my life.—I know the cares, the anxieties of a father for the happineſs of his child; but I cannot endure the idea of your ſuffering a care which I can remove ſo eaſily.—My good friend, I cannot enſure your child's future happineſs; but, at leaſt, I can contribute to it, and to your caſe, by removing your fears of future poverty for her. Happily, as I have married my daughter
with wealth beyond her wants or wiſhes, I cannot permit a man, a father like myſelf, to ſtruggle with a fear ſo painful, as that of his daughter's future ſubſiſtence. (He takes out his pocket-book.) My good friend take theſe notes; this is worth an hundred pounds, this is worth fifty; the ſum they will produce will ſufficiently ſupport you in your old age, and your children when death obliges you to quit them.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: But, your Honour—what—I do not underſtand.

sp.speaker: Colonel Neſbit.
sp.p: My good old man, theſe notes are yours.—Do me the favour to accept them.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Oh Heavens!—What goodneſs!—Is this poſſible!—Surely I dream!

sp.speaker: Colonel Neſbit.
sp.p:
Ah, virtuous old man, let us not think a common
act of kindneſs ſo extraordinary as to diſbelieve its reality!

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Ah, Sir!—a common act!

sp.speaker: Colonel Neſbit.
sp.p:
Let us ſay no more of it!—The notes are yours; and believe me. I feel more plea
••• e in giving than you do in receiving them.—You will, perhaps, chuſe to purchaſe a little farm; which may deſcend to your children's children

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Ah, yes, Sir, and they ſhall learn to bleſs your name, to honour your goodneſs!—In ſpring, when they ſee the opening bloſſoms; in autumn, when they gather in harveſt; they ſhall, next to their God, love and bleſs your name.

sp.speaker: Colonel Neſbit.
sp.p: My good old friend!—let me not hear any more of this.—I wiſh not to draw obſervation.

stage.hi: ('Squire and Lady Aubrey, Miſs Neſbit, and Lucetta, come towards them.)

sp.speaker: Lady Aubrey.
sp.p: What is the matter, my dear Sir?—you ſeem affected.

sp.speaker: Lucetta.
sp.p: Father, what is the matter—I ſaw you change colour.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Yes, my child!—Come hither, Lucetta—all my cares for thee are at an end!—His Honour!—Oh, beſt of men?

sp.speaker: Miſs Neſbit.
sp.p: What does all this mean?

sp.speaker: Lady Aubrey.
sp.p: Tell us, my dear Sir—explain the cauſe of this good man's emotion.

sp.speaker: Colonel Neſbit.
sp.p: Nothing, my children: nothing my friend.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, pardon me; if I diſobey you. Look here, my good Sir▪ ſee 〈…〉 —His Honour has moſt liberally bleſſed me! (He ſhows the notes.)

sp.speaker: Lady Aubrey.
sp.p: Ah, my dear father, what goodneſs!

sp.speaker: Colonel Neſbit.
sp.p: Dear Julia!—Bleſt as I am in my children, happy as I feel in your marriage, could I bear to ſee a father full of care, which I could ſo eaſily relieve?
sp.stage: (Lady Aubrey throws herſelf into his arms, while Miſs Neſbit kiſſes his hand.)

sp.speaker: Lady Aubrey.
sp.p: My father, how my heart thanks you!

sp.speaker: Colonel Neſbit.
sp.p: Silly girls!—What is there in all this to excite ſurprize?

sp.speaker: 'Squire Aubrey.
sp.p: No, my dear Sir, acts of goodneſs are with you too common to excite ſurprize; but I am angry with you.

sp.speaker: Lady Aubrey.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: 'Squire Aubrey.
sp.p:
Yes, my dear Julia your father has invaded ou •
rights.—We ought to aſſiſt and encourage ſuch of our tenants as are deſerving.—My good Robert well merits our attention, and your father ſhall not rob us of the pleaſure of aſſiſting him.

sp.speaker: Lady Aubrey.
sp.p: I am quite of your opinion.

sp.speaker: Colonel Neſbit.
sp.p: So, ſo, I am to be chid amongſt you, it ſeems.

sp.speaker: 'Squire Aubrey.
sp.p: Not if you will permit us to join your benevolent attentions.

sp.speaker: Colonel Neſbit.
sp.p: Oh, with all my heart.
sp.stage: (During this converſation, Robert, Philip, and Lucetta, with great marks of pleaſure and ſurprize, have been looking at the notes, and talking apart.)

sp.speaker: 'Squire Aubrey.
sp.p: Come hither, my friends?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Yes, pleaſe your Honour▪

sp.speaker: 'Squire Aubrey.
sp.p: My good Robert I remember you many years, and from that remembrance, as well as the general report, I know you to be a worthy induſtrious man.—Had I been earlier at the Park, I ſhould have known of this wedding before hand, and I ſhould have thought it my duty to give you ſomething towards your daughter's portion.—It is not yet too late.—Therefore, I promiſe you half a dozen ſheep, two cows, two pigs, a ſtock of poultry, provided you make Lucetta the manager of your farm-yard.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Oh Heavens!—I am over powered.

sp.speaker: 'Squire Aubrey.
sp.p:
As to you, Philip, when a man is married, he ought to have a houſe for his wife; you ſhall therefore have the tenement next to Robert's with the field behind it; for the firſt year it ſhall
be 〈◊〉 -free, after which we will agree on ſuch a rent as you will • nd yourſelf able to pay, and that becauſe I do not deſire to ſet you above the neceſſity of being induſtrious.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Thank you, my Lord, for that, more than all the reſt.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Oh, my Lord!—I cannot thank you as I ought. (He 〈◊〉 to Lucetta, takes her by the hand and ſays) thank God, Lucetta, I have a home for the • .—Ah, my dear, help me to thank our benevolent landlord.
sp.stage: (They go towards 'Squire Aubrey, and attempt to throw themſelves at his feet; he prevents them.)

sp.speaker: Lady Aubrey,
sp.p:
(wiping her eyes.) See, ſiſter, how malicious they are!—They want to prevent our having a ſhare in their pleaſure!—But it remains for us, my pretty Lucetta, to furniſh your houſe, and
to give you a ſtock of groceries.

sp.speaker: Miſs Neſbit.
sp.p: You are right, ſiſter; and of that ſatisfaction we will not be deprived.

sp.speaker: Lucetta,

p.hi: (throwing herſelf at Lady Aubrey's feet, and kiſſing her hand.)

sp.p: Forgive my boldneſs, my Lady, I can only thank you by my tears!

sp.speaker: Robert,
sp.p: Oh, my God! theſe are thy bleſſings, and I thank thee with ſincerity and truth! beſeeching thee to render my benefactors as happy during life as I am at this moment!

sp.speaker: Colonel Neſbit.
sp.p: Good old man, we are debtors to you for the kindneſs of your prayers!—But we have interrupted your amuſements; we will depart.

sp.speaker: 'Squire Aubrey
sp.p: Let us ſee you at the Park, to dinner, to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Lady Aubrey.
sp.p: Ah, Laura, I wiſh we could teach ſome of our city friends how much more exquiſite is the pleaſure derived from an evening like this, than from being ſhut up in a room with wax-lights and cards, or even in the Aſſembly or Play-houſe.

sp.speaker: 'Squire Aubrey.
sp.p: Farewel, my good friends, continue your mirth.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Our bleſſings attend your Honours.

sp.speaker: Lady Aubrey.
sp.p: Farewel, Lucetta!
sp.stage: (They go out, and after a dance of the Peaſants, the Scene cloſes.)

div.head: THE Mocking Bird's Neſt.
A DIALOGUE.
div.p: IT being the ſeaſon when the Spring Vacation took place at ſchool, which interval Mrs. Woodfield embraced for enjoying with her little family the delights of a rural retreat. The beauty of the country daily increaſed; the ſpring was mild and forward. Her little boys William and Thomas had left ſchool about ten days.

Their ſiſters and their little female kinsfolk were now employed for ſome hours every morning in aſſiſting to repair the children's
linen, or making up new againſt their return to ſchool, after the vacation.

The firſt day after their arrival, the boys amuſed themſelves by walking through the woods, which were already in leaf. The reluctant oak and the timid aſh, no longer reſiſting the warmth of the ſun, were rapidly unfolding their freſh leaves. The hedges and underwood were every where green and afforded concealment and ſhelter to an infinite number of birds, now buſy in building their neſts.

In the courſe of their walk, little Thomas, who had wandered on before, came running back out of breath, without his hat, which he held in his hand, and in which, with delight ſparkling in his eyes, he ſhowed his brother a neſt of young unfledged birds.

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: Oh, William! ſee my dear William, what a neſt of birds! The boys there, that have taken them, ſay they are mocking-birds. Mamma, tell me if I may buy them? They aſk only twenty-five cents for them. I will give half of them to William.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Mamma, are they mocking birds? May we have them?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Woodfield.
sp.p: Indeed, I am afraid they are mocking birds: and they are ſo tender, that you will never be able to raiſe them, ſo that to take them ſeems to be wanton cruelty.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p:
But mamma, theſe are taken already; and I am ſure, if they are the tendereſt little things in the world, my ſiſter Matilda will nurſe them up. Don't you remember how ſhe nurſed the young
yellow-birds, which the cat threw down from the peach tree in the garden?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Woodfield.
sp.p: Poor, little, unfortunate creatures! ſee how they pant! I have no other objection to your buying them, my dear William, than as I think it encourages idle boys to continue their cruel robberies on the birds. But, however, as theſe poor mocking birds are priſoners, I believe we may reſcue them out of worſe hands, by taking them into ours. Can the boys there tell you where they took them from; perhaps, after they are out of ſight, we may be able to put them back into the tree where they were hatched.
sp.stage: (The two boys go, though with ſome reluctance, and aſk the bird-ſellers to ſhow them the place.)

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: (returning to his mother.) Mamma, the boys ſay they got this neſt out of a cherry-tree, quite in the very middle of the wood, almoſt a mile off; and they don't believe they can find the place for ever ſo much.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Woodfield.
sp.p:
Well, my loves, then pay for your purchaſe, and we will do the beſt we can with it. Your luckleſs little captives will ſoon be hungry, and we ſhall find nothing to give them here; therefore, I would have you Jane, with your two uncles, go home, and find a ſecure cage for your mocking birds, which muſt ſtill, however, remain in the neſt; and let your maid Rachael, aſſiſt you in feeding them, as ſhe is fond of ſuch things, and underſtands ſomething of them. Matilda, Eliza, and I, ſhall continue our walk, as I have
ſome buſineſs with a woman at the village who is ſpinning for me.
sp.stage: (The children go back to the houſe.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: See how carefully little Thomas ſteps with his treaſure.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Woodfield.
sp.p: He will be an excellent nurſe to them, and ſo will William, as far as their judgment goes; but theſe unfortunate objects of childiſh tenderneſs are not unfrequently killed by kindneſs. Neither of my little fellows have that diſpoſition to cruelty which is ſaid to be inherent in human nature, and which I have ſometimes thought really is ſo, however degrading the idea may be.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: I am ſure I have thought ſo, very often, when I have ſeen how cruel ſome people are to animals.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Woodfield.
sp.p:
It is indeed, not
only humiliating, but it is to my feelings ſo diſtreſſing, that I ſeldom have paſſed through any great towns, without ſeeing ſome inſtance of human cruelty and animal ſuffering that has dwelt upon my mind, and affected my ſpirits for the reſt of the day.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: And is it impoſſible to puniſh ſuch horrid monſters?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Woodfield.
sp.p:
The ſufferings of theſe miſerable victims of human barbarity have not been, and therefore, I ſuppoſe, cannot be ſufficiently attended to by the legiſlature. An hackney-coach-man may whip his galled and tired horſe with impunity, though the exhauſted animal has not ſtrength to execute the taſk his brutal driver demands of him; for what poſitive law is there againſt a man's whipping his horſes? or how ſhall his management
of them be regulated. Were I a man, I am perſuaded I ſhould turn knight-errant in defence of the mere animal, againſt what are improperly called reaſonable beings. How beautifully does the inimitable COWPER treat this ſubject! Speaking of the domeſtic animal dependant on man, he ſays,—
They prove too often at how dear a rate
He fells protection. Witneſs at his foot
The Spaniel dying for ſome venial fault,
Under diſſection of the knotted ſcourge:
Witneſs the patient ox, with ſtripes and yells
Driven to the ſlaughter, goaded, as he runs,
To madneſs; while the ſavage at his heels
Laughs at the frantic ſufferer's • ury ſpent
Upon the guiltleſs paſſenger o'erthrown.
He, too, is witneſs, nobleſt of the train
That wait on man, the fleet performing horſe
With unſuſpecting readineſs he takes
His murderer on his back; and puſh'd all day,
With bleeding ſides, and flanks that heave for life,
To the far diſtant goal arrives—and dies.
Does LAW, ſo jealous in the cauſe of man,
Denounce no loom on the delinquent?—None.
And alas! this is one of thoſe evils that ſatire, excellent and juſt even as this is, can do but little to correct; for, as ſome periodical work, (I think the World,) in one of its eſſays, obſerves, coachmen, draymen, cartmen, and drovers, do not read eſſays; yet I have often fancied that ſomething might be done to ſoften the cruel hearts of the lower claſſes of people, if any perſon of abilities would adopt remonſtrances to their comprehenſion,
and teach them to fear hereafter ſuch puniſhments as they now inflict, in dreadful retaliation.

They were by this time arrived at the village, whoſe few ſtraggling houſes edged the extenſive wood, and in a neat cottage found a decently dreſſed woman, whoſe huſband was a farmer, and who was employed by Mrs. Woodfield to ſpin for her. She deſired the woman to bring out ſome flax in its raw ſtate; deſcribed the proceſs of making it into tow, fit for ſpinning, and then made each of the girls ſpin a thread. Not far from thence, in the ſame village, was a loom; they there ſaw it woven into ſheeting and other coarſe linen. Their walk home was deſignedly varied. Mrs. Woodfield led them acroſs a ruſtic bridge, and along the banks of a rapid ſtream that turned a paper-mill,
into which they entered, and ſaw the whole operation of making ſeveral kinds of paper. She then explained to them the materials and means by which it was made; and bade them carry their imagination back, from the ſtalk of the flax they had ſeen, bearing a blue and ſimple flower trembling on its ſlender ſummit, through all its changes and modifications till it contributes to make a ſheet of paper.

This ſpeculation amuſed them for the reſt of their walk. On their arrival at home, Matilda and Eliza, were agreeably ſurpriſed by a card they found upon their table, from a gentleman of their acquaintance, inviting the whole family to one of Mr. Duport's much admired Fancy Balls.

Pleaſure danced in the eyes of Matilda, when ſhe found Mrs.
Woodfield intended to return an anſwer that they would accept this invitation. Nor was Eliza much leſs delighted. An immediate conſultation was held as to the arrangement neceſſary; and Mrs. Woodfield, leaving them to enjoy this antepaſt of pleaſure, (all that life's deception frequently allow as to taſte, and which is at their ages ſo keenly taſted,) went to inſpect the little menagerie of the three younger children, lately increaſed by their mocking birds, about which they were anxiouſly employed. It was more neceſſary to repreſs their ill-judged ſolicitude, than to reprove them for careleſsneſs of their little charge. But deſirous of teaching them to reflect, ſhe made uſe of the preſent opportunity; when the eldeſt of the two boys ſaid, "Mamma, I do not believe
theſe little birds would be more comfortable if they were with their own mother."

sp.speaker: Mrs. Woodfield.
sp.p: Admitting it to be ſo, my dear William (though I greatly fear it is not the fact) pray tell me what you think is the opinion of their own mother.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Perhaps ſhe may be a little ſorry, when ſhe comes back and finds the neſt gone.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Woodfield.
sp.p: William! how do you think I ſhould feel, if, on my return from a journey, where I had been to procure money to pay for the ſubſiſtence of my children, I found my houſe vacant; and that ſome tyrant, whom I could not purſue or puniſh, had taken them from me, and condemned them to impriſonment or death? Tell me, William; and do you, Thomas, tell me, how do you think your mamma would feel?

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: (looking earneſtly and ſorrowful) Certainly mamma, you would cry, and be very unhappy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Woodfield.
sp.p:
Juſt ſo muſt the birds' mother feel, when ſhe returns and finds the vacant bough from which her neſt has been torn. But, to impreſs this more forcibly on your memory, William, you ſhall learn by rote, and write theſe lines in your copy-book:
Oft when returning with her loaded 〈◊〉
Th' aſtoniſhed mother finds a vacant neſt,
By the hard hands of unrelenting clowns
Robb'd; to the ground the vain proviſion falls;
Her pinions ruffle, and, low drooping, ſcarce
Can bear the mourner to the poplar ſhade.

sp.speaker: Thomas
sp.p:
(with tears ſtarting in his eyes.) Mamma, if I had thought about what the old bird muſt feel,
I would have made the boys I bought them of, put the neſt back again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Woodfield.
sp.p:
If you had done ſo, my dear little boy, it would hardly, in this caſe, have anſwered your humane intention; for thoſe idle boys, as ſoon as you are out of ſight, would have taken the neſt again, and have ſold the poor birds to ſome other perſon. What I mean is, not only to induce you to take care of them, ſince they now depend on you, but to engage you, in every caſe, to put yourſelf in the place of whatever creature you are about to injure or oppreſs; that you may acquire a habit of ſaying to yourſelf, How ſhould I like to be treated thus? What ſhould I ſuffer, if I were in the place of the cat we are wantonly hunting with our terriers? of the robbins which
we are wounding with our arrows? of the ducks we are ſetting the ſpaniels at? Whoever learns early in life to make theſe reflexions, will never have a reproach to make himſelf on the ſcore of humanity, either towards the animal, or the human ſpecies.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: But, mamma, grown people hunt, and ſhoot, and fiſh, and do not ſeem to think there is any cruelty in it!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Woodfield.
sp.p:
So far as it becomes neceſſary to kill for our ſupport, the animals Providence has allotted for us, there is nothing criminal in it; but to prolong their tortures is highly ſo, or want only to deſtroy any living creatures that are innoxious. For to-morrow's taſk, Thomas ſhall write out for me theſe lines, on the ſubject of inferior animals, and even reptiles and inſects:
—If man's convenience, health.
Or ſafety interfere, his rights and claims
Are paramount, and muſt extinguiſh theirs;
Elſe they are all, the meaneſt things that are,
As free to live and to enjoy that life,
As God was free to form them at the firſt,
Who in his ſovereign wiſdom made them all▪
Ye, therefore, who love mercy, teach your ſons to love it too.—
And now, my dear boys, you muſt releaſe your niece Jane, for ſhe is going out to-morrow evening, and I fancy has ſome little preparation to make. My dear Jane, follow me.

div.stage: SCENE, A room above ſtairs—MATILDA and ELIZA conſulting about their Dreſs.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p:
I dare ſay I ſhall look is horribly old-faſhioned as poſſible;
it is five months ſince I have ſeen any creature who could tell me what they wear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Woodfield.
sp.p: (entering) "What they wear!" there is no term in the whole cant of frivolity that is half ſo diſguſting to me as that▪ Who are they, my dear Matilda, to whoſe mode of dreſs you are determined to pay ſuch obſequious deference?

sp.speaker: Matilda
sp.p: (confuſed). Nay, ma'am, I mean people that—people that are in the world you know—that is—people—in ſhort . . . .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Woodfield.
sp.p:
That are not twaddles and quizzes, and grubs and goodies, and half an hundred other odd names, that you give to the folks you uſually meet with in the country. Tell me now, Matilda, if it would not have afforded you great pleaſure, had you known
of this ball ſoon enough, to have written ſ • ily to your faſhionable friend, Miſs Freemantle, to have ſent you ſome very whimſical dreſs, with a new name, ſuch as you imagine, having never been ſeen in this country, would make people ſtare?

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: I ſhould not have ventured to have done it without your leave.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Woodfield.
sp.p: But, however, it would have given you pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Certainly; I ſhould not like to appear any where but properly dreſſed, if I could help it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Woodfield.
sp.p: And after all, what is ſo proper for a young perſon of your age, as perfect ſimplicity and neatneſs? You are ſtill in mourning, and would not, I hope▪ have thrown it off an hour ſooner on account of this public ball.

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: But all I am afraid of is, that if one is not a little faſhionable, one looks vulgar.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Woodfield.
sp.p:
It is infinitely more vulgar to appear at ſuch an aſſembly over-dreſt. Believe me, my dear, mere dreſs contributes nothing to that look of elegance, or, if you will, of ſuperiority, that you ſeem ſo jealous of. You will be convinced of this, if you ſhould ſee to-morrow evening, as you probably will, a lady, named Scarfton, who is the firſt and fineſt at all our public balls; ſhe is the wife of a man in trade of conſiderable credit, who is often to Great Britain, as he is engaged in buſineſs there. This woman, who is extremely homely, is the greateſt adept in faſhions I ever ſaw. She runs about for a week before the commencement of the public aſſemblies,
from milliner to milliner, to ſee other ladies' cloaths, and then imagines ſomething like the moſt remarkable, with which to induce ſome attention towards her. Her cloaths are made up in every variety of extravagant faſhion, and each habiliment has ſome out-landiſh name that ſhe cannot even pronounce. Without the leaſt regard to proportion or propriety, ſhe dreſſeſs out her unfortunate perſon in the wildeſt mode of the wildeſt girl of faſhion, and the effect is, that ſhe creates envy in the weak, and pity in the wiſe; and, while ſhe thinks herſelf on the very pinnacle of politeneſs and elegance, I ſee ſome look upon her as a mad woman, and all conſider her as bordering on inſanity. Have you any ambition, Matilda, to ſhare, with ſuch a woman as Mrs. Scarfton,
the ſtate of public amazement?

sp.speaker: Matilda.
sp.p: Dear ma'am, can you ſuppoſe I have?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Woodfield.
sp.p:
Let us hear no more, then of wiſhes to know what they • ear. My mantua-maker, who makes cloaths for ſuch as are eſteemed faſhionable, often forces me to ſmile, by adviſing me to have my gown made ſo and ſo, aſſuring me they wear them ſo: and when I aſk who •
ſhe ſimperingly informs me, that Miſs K •• ty Doeſkin, daughter of Mr. Doeſkin, an eminent leather dreſſer, and Miſs Clutterbucks, daughter of Mr. Clutterbucks, green-grocer and dealer, have had new dreſſes from London, "quite in taſte," which they have given me leave to look at.

div.p:
Such are the hiſtories of faſhions. The belles, who derive their information
from the Miſs Doeſkins and the Miſs Clutterbucks, will take the lead in elegance, till Mrs. Scarfton's huſband arrives next from London, then the ton of articles a la Doeſ • ins and Clutterbucks, will be entirely ſuperſeded by the knowledge acquired by the happier few, who, are admitted 〈◊〉 contempla • e the ſuperior elegance of the lady's of that houſe.

Do you think, Matilda, ſuch • hemeron triumphs as theſe, are worth a moment's thought? I am far, however, from wiſhing you entirely to decline appearing in what is called in the faſhion; ſuch affection would be as ridiculous on one hand, as running into its wildeſt exceſſes is on the other. A young woman ſhould dreſs as the perſons of her age dreſs, but without ſacrificing decency, common
ſenſe, or proportion. Nothing, perhaps, is a more glaring abſurdity, among all the weakneſſes women are charged with, than the undiſtinguiſhing avidity with which women of all ranks, ages and figures, run into modes of d •• ſs that neither ſuits the perſon or pockets of all, and probably disfigures five out of ſix. Some ſlender girl of faſhion imagines, in the caprice of imputed perfections, 〈◊〉 manner of dreſſing which ſhall ſhow every • ne of thoſe perfections. It ſucceeds; the men compliment, the Miſſes envy, and the mob wonder. In a few days, the fat red-faced matron of fifty; the dwarfiſh Miſs, who has owed her little conſequence to her heels and her head; the round ſnug damſel, as thick as ſhe is long; and the genteel young lady, that has lived on vinegar till ſhe is reduced
to a ſtudy for an anatomiſt: all follow the faſhion: but hardly are they eſtabliſhed in it, before ſome other, more prepoſterous ſucceeds; and the former,
Like the baſeleſs fabric of a viſion,
Leaves not a wreck behind;
unleſs it be in that deſcription of perſons who, in Shakeſpeare's time were called,
The velvet guards, and Sunday citizens.

I have often thought, that if were poſſible to have a ſet of dolls dreſſed in the faſhions of the laſt two hundred years, it would be an amuſing ſpectacle, and not without its uſe, as a leſſon to human vanity. The modes are now forgotten, and the names of the triflers who invented them are forgotten too; the only memorial that remains of either exiſts, perhaps, in ſome book,
where they are accidentally alluded to, and which the commentary of the antiquarian and the critic may have explained.

It ſhould be a leſſon to the ſpangled butterfly of the paſſing day, and it ſhould teach her the ſuperiority of Intellect over Beauty, when ſhe reflects, that the charms of ſo many lovely women live now only in the memory of mankind by the poets who have celebrated their names. Even the beautiful Lady Coventry is obliged to Maſon for telling us what ſhe was. "The liquid luſtre of her eyes," is thought of but faintly by thoſe who read of the incomparably faſcinating charms that graced her perſon. There is a ſ • nnet of Drayton's addreſſed to a lady, whoſe merit he glories in being able to reſcue from 〈◊〉 , which is appoſite to this
topic. It is not ſo poliſhed as modern poetry; but is highly expreſſive of his opinion of the power of poeſy, and of thoſe objects of tranſient admiration, of whom it has been ſaid, THEY had no POET and THEY died.

lg.l: How many fooliſh, paltry, painted things,
That now in coaches trouble every ſtreet,
Shall be forgotten—whom no poet ſings
E'er they are well wrapped in their winding ſheet;
But 〈◊〉 to t ••• eternity ſhall give,
When nothing elſe remaineth of thoſe days,
And queens hereafter ſhall be glad to live
Upon the alms of my ſuper •• uous praiſe.
Virgins and matrons, reading thus my rhymes.
Shall be ſo much delighted with 〈◊◊〉 .
That they ſhall grieve they lived not in theſe times,
To have ſeen thee, their ſexes greateſt glory.
For thou ſhalt ſoar above the vulgar throng,
And ſtill ſurvive in my immortal Song▪
